entry.title: How SAP’s AI Agent Architecture Enables Unprecedented Automation and Decision Augmentation
entry.content:
AI agents are redefining business applications. Enabled by advanced reasoning capabilities, they plan, act, reflect, and collaborate to perform tasks and make decisions based on data and predefined business objectives. These agents have the potential to automate business processes and act as assistants for human users, reimagining how work is structured, how decisions are made, and how value is created. Here you can find out more about AI Agent use cases and the value they provide.

Looking back at SAP Sapphire on May 20-21, 2025, we are at the forefront of agents with the launch of an expanded network of Joule Agents, the AI agent hub in SAP LeanIX and the announcement of the agent builder capability in Joule Studio.

This blog post is the first of a series that dives deeper into various aspects of SAP’s AI agent offerings and their technical underpinnings and architecture.

SAP’s AI Agent Strategy

At SAP we run the most mission critical business processes end-to-end through the broadest application portfolio in the industry. With more than 75% of the world's transaction revenue touching an SAP software system, SAP is uniquely positioned to embed AI agents into business processes to drive value. We view AI agents as an integral part of our strategy, seamlessly integrating them across all our cloud applications and BTP.  SAP Business Data Cloud preserves the business context and semantics of your business data, providing the foundation for these agents. This powerful cycle – connecting applications, data, and agents – unlocks unprecedented value for our customers. 

We are committed to designing relevant, reliable and responsible AI agents centered around the human user, automating or supporting them in their daily tasks and decision-making. So, how do we make this a reality? 

SAP’s Architecture for AI Agents 

Businesses must move beyond traditional software systems toward AI-native solutions, where business logic, user interfaces, data access, and governance are inherently designed for agentic collaboration. At SAP, we are fundamentally evolving our approach to business applications as we tackle this once-in-a-generation opportunity. Rather than encoding domain expertise and best practices into pre-defined workflows, we now ground the future of AI agents in that very expertise, enabling more dynamic, adaptive, and intelligent systems. 

SAP specializes in business agents. Our teams are developing a wide range of pre-built SAP agent use cases centered around high-impact areas such as customer experience, supply chain management, spend management, finance, and human capital management. These agents are relevant since they are embedded in your business applications and processes right from the start.

SAP introduced Joule as the omnipresent conversational entry point for AI, enabling simple and efficient human and agent interactions across all our applications and your browser. We are shifting from traditional user interfaces – separate dashboards for analytics, enterprise search, and business processes – toward a unified, AI-driven experience that seamlessly integrates them all. What sets Joule apart is that it is agentic by design, capable of reasoning, planning, and orchestrating actions across multiple agents to solve even the most complex tasks. Beyond conversational triggers, we empower agents to be activated by business events, workflows, or applications to maximize the potential of AI agent automation.

Acknowledging our diverse customer landscapes, rather than imposing a one-size-fits-all solution, we provide our customers the flexibility to extend and configure SAP-built agents in Joule Studio. This enables you to fine-tune our agents to your processes or adapt them to work with third-party solutions. To meet customers’ needs for a business agent development platform, your developers can build your own agents via Joule Studio or agent SDKs to tap into previously unrealized potential. 

To power your custom low-code no-code agents as well as SAP-built Joule Agents, we offer a managed agent runtime as part of SAP AI Foundation. This runtime features deeply researched agent flows and reasoning capabilities, along with a seamless integration into your SAP and non-SAP software systems right out of the box. For this, we leverage a combination of reason and act, plan and solve, and custom steps for grounding, reflection and consecutive learning.

We view both structured and unstructured data as key strategic assets for AI, equipping our agents with a comprehensive suite of data access tools. However, data alone is not enough, AI also needs access to the underlying semantics and relationships. SAP Business Data Cloud preserves your business context and semantics of all your mission-critical SAP and third-party data with an open data ecosystem. Together with knowledge retrieval and grounding capabilities – powered by resources such as SAP Knowledge Graph and document grounding – this makes our agents inherently reliable, as they are rooted in your company’s information, policies, and files. From day one, these agents can explore and deeply understand your business systems, processes, and domain data, bolstered by SAP’s extensive industry and process expertise. Through our partnership with Perplexity, our agents can even conduct in-depth research across external data sources to enhance your business decisions.

Our agents utilize Joule functions as integration tools to interact with their environment and business systems. Joule functions address essential concerns like security and connectivity centrally, ensuring smooth connectivity of our agents to your business systems. Furthermore, reusable agent tools, including web search and code execution, enhance agent capabilities.

As enterprises deploy numerous AI agents, orchestration and collaboration among those agents become critical. To enable use cases spanning multiple vendors and domains, our agent and tool registry along with support for agent interoperability protocols (e.g. MCP, A2A), allow customers and partners to incorporate their own tools or agents from external vendors, fostering an open agent ecosystem and marketplace.

Responsibility is at the core of our AI agent design, adhering to SAP’s stringent AI privacy and security standards. Every action taken by agents on behalf of users is audit-logged and personal data is filtered, while industry-leading identity and access management with dedicated agent identities and authorizations ensures secure automation without compromise.

We recognize that despite the utility of AI agents, humans remain integral to business decision-making and reasoning. Therefore, we deliberately design our AI agents following our AI ethics policy and to keep humans in the loop to review and approve work done or proposed by AI agents. Thanks to advanced explainability techniques, users can trace and fully understand each AI-driven decision or action, allowing for intervention or guidance whenever necessary. Through robust monitoring and governance services, alongside AI agent hub in SAP LeanIX, we ensure humans remain in control.

Conclusion

By seamlessly integrating pre-built Joule Agents into our business processes, applications, and SAP BTP, we are dedicated to unlocking unprecedented value for our customers. We empower our customers to create custom agents and enable extensibility of SAP agents through Joule Studio. By enabling interoperability, we cultivate a vibrant agent ecosystem ready to adapt and grow. Our strategy is centered around building trust, ensuring control, and enhancing business readiness – key components for maximizing the transformative potential of AI agents.

Looking ahead, we are committed to staying ahead of the rapidly evolving AI landscape, continually exploring and innovating in this exciting field. In the upcoming six months, we plan to further refine our platform for agents and expand our coverage of high value use cases. To fully tap into the potential of automation, we're concentrating on the next generation of AI agents: system-triggered agents that proactively create solutions before issues even become apparent. By forging strong partnerships with Google, Mistral, NVIDIA and Perplexity, our agents will be well-equipped for the future.

Join us on a journey to explore the technical foundations that empower our business agents and stay tuned for the next parts of this series covering: 

  • Unifying AI Workloads with SAP HANA Cloud: One Database for All Your Data Models
  • Reasoning and Planning in Joule: the Omnipresent Orchestrator for Agents and AI
  • AI Tooling and Data Foundation with SAP Business Data Cloud and SAP Knowledge Graph
  • Building content-based AI Agents with Joule Studio or code-based Agents with AI Foundation
  • Enterprise-grade Security and Access Control for AI Agents
  • Agent Interoperability and Ecosystem with A2A and MCP

Co-authored by Dr. Jan Dumke and Alex Schaefer

entry.title: How to Build Stock Validation Skills in Joule Studio
entry.content:
Build Maintenance Validation Skills Using Joule Studio  in SAP Build (Part 1)

Intro: Empowering Maintenance Operations with Joule Skills

Joule Studio enables business users and developers to build Joule Skills that automate backend tasks and simplify decision-making. In this hands-on guide — the first of a two-part series —We’ll walk through creating a set of Joule Skills that help retrieve maintenance orders, fetch material and component details, and check stock availability, forming the foundation for intelligent decision-making, using a CAP-based service on SAP BTP.

We’ll focus specifically on how to design, build, and test Joule Skills inside Joule Studio. The backend logic used to check maintenance order status and stock availability is already deployed as a reusable service on SAP BTP and exposed through a destination.  

Use Case: Intelligent Maintenance Stock Validation 

Maintenance planners often face delays when required components for maintenance orders are unavailable. The validation process today is manual and error prone. 

With Joule Studio, we can automate this. Our Joule Skills we’ll build will: 

  • Retrieve pending maintenance orders 
  • Identify components required 
  • Check material stock availability 
  • Return the result to the user or agent consuming the skill

 

Now that we've outlined the business challenge and solution approach, let's dive into the hands-on implementation. We'll build this step-by-step, starting with the foundational setup and progressing through skill creation.

Prerequisites

Before we begin building our maintenance validation skills, you'll need access to Joule Studio. If you don't have Joule Studio set up yet, please follow the comprehensive setup guide available at: How to Get Started with Joule Studio

This guide will walk you through:

  • Accessing Joule Studio in your SAP BTP environment
  • Setting up the necessary entitlements and subscriptions
  • Configuring your development environment
  • Understanding the basic Joule Studio interface

Our Development Approach:

  1. First, we'll establish the connection to our backend service.
  2. Then, we'll create individual skills for each business function.
  3. Finally, we'll test and deploy our skills for use.

Step 1: Configure the Destination in SAP Build Lobby 

To connect Joule Studio to the backend service, you’ll first configure a destination directly in the SAP Build Control Tower. 

This destination will point to an already deployed CAP service that exposes the necessary maintenance order and stock validation logic. 

Create a New Destination 

  1. Navigate to the SAP Build Lobby .
  2. Go to Control Tower > Destinations.
  3. Click “Open in BTP Cockpit”.
  4. In the BTP Cockpit, Navigate to:
    • Connectivity > Destinations

 

5. Click Create Destination and fill in the following configuration: 

  • Name: sample-maintenance-service 
  • Type: HTTP 
  • Description: Maintenance Order Service
  • URL: https://sample-maintenance-srv-i760021.cfapps.eu12.hana.ondemand.com/odata/v4/maintenance-order 
  • Proxy Type: Internet 
  • Authentication: BasicAuthentication 
  • User: TECHNICAL_USER 
  • Password: TECHNICAL_PASS

 

 

 

6.  Click Check Connection to verify the destination. You should see a green checkmark if the connection is successful.

Step 2: Create an Environment in SAP Build 

Before adding destinations or creating skills in Joule Studio, you need to create an environment in SAP Build. This environment acts as the runtime space where your agents and skills will be deployed and executed. 

To create an environment: 

  1. Open the SAP Build Lobby 
  2. Navigate to Control Tower > Environments 
  3. Click Create Environment 
  4. Enter a name for your environment, e.g., Joule studio demo 
  5. (Optional) Add a description if needed 
  6. Click Create 

Later, you’ll associate your destination and actions with this environment to make them usable in your skills and agents 

Step 3: Add the Destination to SAP Build  

Now that your destination is created in BTP, as we did in Step 1, we need to make it available inside SAP Build to use it in Joule Studio. 

  1. Open SAP Build Lobby 
  2. Navigate to Control Tower > Destinations 
  3. Click Add 
  4. In the wizard: Select your destination (e.g. sample-maintenance-service) 
  5. Click Next 
  6. Associate an Environment 
    1. Select the environment you created in Step 2(e.g., Joule_studio_demo) 
    2. You can choose to make the destination available in all environments or only the specific environment which you created in step 2 .
  7. Click Add Destination 

Once added, this destination will now be available to associate with environments and to use in Joule skills. 

Step 4: Add an Action in SAP Build (Expose Your API) 

Now that your destination is available and associated with an environment, the next step is to create an Action that defines how your backend API should be called by Joule skills. 

Actions are the bridge between destinations (backend APIs) and Joule Skills. 

You can upload an open API specification or build an action from scratch using the destination you added. 

Option 1: Upload OpenAPI Spec from Your Project 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions 
  2. Click Create > Upload API Specification 
  3. Note:The API spec is provided as a .txt file containing JSON content in the attachment.
    Before uploading, rename the file to have a .json extension  so Joule Studio correctly detects the format.
  4. Upload your openapi.json file. 
  5. Click Next to continue 
  6. You’ll now be prompted to Create an Action Project. 
  7. Fill in Project Name and Description according to your use case.
    • For example, you can name the project Maintenance Fulfillment Agent API , since these APIs will later be used by a Joule Agent (covered in Part 2 of this series). 
  8. After creating the action project, you will see a list of all endpoints from your uploaded specification (you can select maximum up to 20) 
    • Select all the 6 endpoints needed for your use case. 
    • Click Add to include them in the project. 

8. Once the action is created, go to the Test tab and select the destination you created. Since the maintenance order API lists all orders, no input is required by default. If you'd like to filter by status (e.g., pending, open), you can add that later as an input parameter. Click Test to verify that the API returns a valid response. 

 

9. You should see 200: OK response from the API. 

Once tested, you can release the project to create a version of it. 

 

 10.Once released, click Publish to make the version available for Joule Skill creation 

Note: Releasing and publishing the action is required. Unpublished actions won’t appear when building a Joule Skill. 

Option 2: Alternatively: Build the Action from Scratch 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions 
  2. Click Create > Build from Scratch 
  3. Fill in the required fields: 
    • Operation: GET 
    • Name: Enter a name for your action (e.g., CheckMaintenanceStock) 
    • Description: Enter a brief description (e.g., Checks stock for components in a maintenance order) 
    • Endpoint: eg., /MaintenanceOrder) 
  4. Define any request parameters and expected response fields. 
  5. Click Release and Publish the action just like in the previous method for the actions to be available. 

For our use case, we will be using Option 1. 

Step 5: Create a Project and Joule Skills 

Now that the destination is configured, the environment is created, and your action has been added and published, you’re ready to build a custom Joule Skill that calls the required API from your service. 

These skills will be reusable and can later be connected to an intelligent agent in Part 2 of this series.

Create a New Skill Project 

  1. Open Joule Studio in SAP Build. 
  2. Click on create > Create Skill  
  3. Enter 
    • Project Name: eg., Intelligent Maintenance Order Stock Validation Agent   
    • Description: e.g., Skills to validate whether maintenance orders can be fulfilled based on stock availability
  4. Note: While we’re only creating Joule Skills in this post, we’ll use the same project to add and configure the Joule Agent in Part 2 of this series.
  5. Click Review > Create 

Once the project is created, you’ll be taken to the Overview tab, where you’ll see the project name and description. 

 

 

The project will be created after you click “Create”.  

Add a New Joule Skill 

  1. In the project, click Create 
  2. From the dropdown, select Joule Skill.
  3. Fill in: 
    • Name: e.g., GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 
    • Identifier: e.g., get-maintenance-order 
    • Description: e.g., get list of a maintenance order  
    • Click Create 

 

 

Add the Parameters to the Skill 

  1. Open the skill by clicking its name or the arrow icon to the left .This is the panel where you need to add input, output parameters.  
  2. In the “General” tab, update the name/description of the Joule skill. 
  3. Keep the toggle “Allow skill to be started directly by a user” ON (so the skill can be started directly by the user, not just via an agent).

     

  4. Go to the Parameters tab. Click Configure to add input and output parameters. 
  5. Inputs allow Joule to collect user input in the conversation interface. 
  6. Outputs define what information will be shown to the user after the skill executes. Add the input parameter: 

➕Add Input 

  1. Add the following Input: 
    • Name: User query 
    • Description: Context for the endpoint to give the list of the orders 
    • Required: Unchecked 
    • Click Apply to save the input. 

➕Add Output 

  1. Add the following Output: 
    • Name: List of Orders 
    • Type: Any 
    • List: Checked 
    • Required: Checked 
    • Description: List of orders depending on the user request (e.g., pending or open orders) 
  2. Click Apply to save the output. 
  3. Output types can vary — choose the appropriate type based on the structure of your API response. 
  4. You’ve now configured both input and output parameters for your Joule skill. 

Add an Action Step to the Skill 

  1. Click the ➕Plus icon to add a step
    1.  
  2. Select Call Action 
  3. In the Action search: 
    • Either browse all actions 
    • Or use the search bar to quickly find your previously published action (e.g., GetMaintenanceOrderDetails) 
    • Click Add 

 

 

 

Configure the Action Step 

  1. After adding the action, you’ll see General, Input, and Output tabs. 
  2. In the General tab: 
    • Set Step Name: Get maintenance orders 
    • For Destination Variable, create or select one (e.g., Fulfillment_agent) 
    • Click Create to add the destination, then select it. 
  3. Go to the Input tab and map the input (e.g., user query). 
  4. In the Output tab, you can view the API’s response schema. 
  5. Click End to configure the skill’s outputs and map the expected output value. 
  6. Click Save to finish the step configuration. 

 

 

Create Skills for Each API Endpoint 

We have already created a skill which uses GET/MaintenanceOrder  

 

Tool Name 

Endpoint 

Description 

GetMaintenanceOrders 

GET /MaintenanceOrder 

Retrieve all maintenance orders (can be filtered) 

GetMaintenanceOrderDetails 

GET /MaintenanceOrder('{ID}') 

Get details of a specific maintenance order 

cGetOrderOperations 

GET /MaintenanceOrder('{ID}')/operation 

List operations under a maintenance order 

GetOperationComponents 

GET /Operation('{ID}')/component 

List components for a specific operation 

GetMaterialDetails 

GET /Material('{ID}') 

Get material details 

GetMaterialStockLevels 

GET /Material('{ID}')/stockLevel 

Check stock availability for a material 

 

For each skill, remember to: 

  • Configure input and output parameters.
  • Set the correct destination variable.
  • Turn on “Allow skill to be started directly by a user” if creating Joule Skills.

Tip: Use the Action Definition to Configure Skill Parameters 

When configuring the Skill Input and Skill Output, you don’t need to guess what the API expects or returns. 

You can find this information directly from the Action definition you uploaded earlier: 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Actions.
  2. Open the Action project you created .
  3. Select the relevant endpoint.
  4. Navigate to the Input and Output tabs 

From there, you can: 

  • See which input parameters are required 
  • Understand the expected output structure and data types 

 

 

 

 

Example: For GET /Operation('{ID}')/component 

  • Input: ID of the operation (marked with a red asterisk = required) .
  • Output: 
    • value → A list of components (type: list) 
    • count → Number of items (type: number) 

Use this information to accurately define the parameters in your Joule Skill > Parameters tab. 

  

Step 6: Release and Deploy Joule Skills 

With your Joule Skills created and configured, the next step is to release and deploy them to your environment so they can be used in real scenarios.

  1. Click Release to version your Project.

  

       2. Go to Project > Versions 

       3. Click Deploy 

 

 

During deployment: 

  1. Select the Environment created in Step 2 (e.g., Joule Studio demo) 
  2. Select the Destination you added in Step 3 
    • You will only see destinations that are: 
      • Associated with this environment 
      • Or made available to All Environments 
  3. Click Deploy 
  4. After deployment, the agent status will appear as Active 

 

 

 

Test the Skills in Joule Studio

To interact with your the skills: 

  1. Go to Control Tower > Environments 
  2. Click your environment (e.g., joule studio demo) 
  3. Under your agent project, click More > Joule 
  4. Click Launch to open the Joule Chat window 

You can now start chatting with your agent using real-world prompts. 

 

For example: 


Debugging Agents Flow 

  • You can open the Debug Panel in the top right corner to see details of how Joule selects the skills based on the user input.  

Example Prompts to Test the Joule skills

  1. “Show me all current maintenance orders” 
  2. “Get details for maintenance order 25” 
  3. “What operations are planned for maintenance order 4?” 
  4. “What is the description of material 19” 
  5. “How many units of material M-45678 are in stock?” 

Wrapping Up Part 1: Skills First, Intelligence Next

In this first part of our Joule Studio blog series, we focused on building the foundation: creating, configuring, and deploying individual Joule Skills that interact with maintenance orders and material data. These skills are now live, testable, and ready to be reused across various automation and intelligence layers.

Each skill is designed to handle a focused task — whether it’s fetching order details, retrieving stock levels, or listing required components. With these deployed, you're now ready to take the next leap: combining them into an intelligent agent.

In Part 2, we’ll build a Joule Agent that brings your deployed skills together into an intelligent assistant — one that can understand maintenance-related questions, check if orders can be fulfilled, identify what’s blocking them, and even suggest solutions such as replenishment needs or follow-up actions.


Part 2 will show you how to build an intelligent maintenance agent that brings your skills to life — stay tuned!

If you're interested in diving deeper into Joule Studio and expanding your knowledge beyond this use case, here are valuable resources to accelerate your learning:

Learning Resources

  • Learning Journey - Comprehensive guided learning path for Joule Studio
  • Documentation - Official technical documentation and reference guides
  • Discovery Center Mission - Hands-on missions to build practical skills
  • Joule Studio Tutorials - Step-by-step development tutorials
  • Architecture Overview - Technical architecture and integration patterns
  • Smart Advisory Companion – Inspiration Video - See Joule Studio in action with real-world scenarios

These resources will help you explore additional use cases, advanced features, and best practices for building intelligent automation solutions with Joule Studio.

entry.title: Queue Browser: Deep Message Visibility for Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

In event-driven architectures, messages flow continuously between systems, carrying critical business data and triggering essential processes. When something goes wrong—messages pile up, integrations fail, or data appears corrupted—you need immediate visibility into what’s happening inside your queues. Without this insight, troubleshooting becomes a frustrating game of guesswork.

Monitoring message queues is essential in event‑driven architectures. It reveals queue health and uncovers bottlenecks, providing crucial delivery and routing insights that ensure system reliability. With the latest release of Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite, we’re excited to announce Queue Browser, a new capability that delivers deep message visibility through an intuitive web‑based interface.

The key advantage: Visualizing and inspecting messages using Queue Browser won't consume them from the message broker queue, so you can safely examine message metadata—such as headers, statuses, and errors—and troubleshoot malformed payloads without disrupting live processing.

What is Queue Browser in Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite?

Queue Browser is a web-based monitoring and diagnostics tool that allows you to inspect messages in a queue without consuming them from the message broker. Think of it as a "read-only window" into your message queues—you can see everything that's happening without affecting the actual message flow.

Queue Browser bridges the gap between high-level queue metrics and detailed application logs, giving you the message-level insight needed for effective troubleshooting.

Key Capabilities

  • Search & Filter: Quickly locate messages by criteria such as message ID, correlation ID, and custom properties.
  • Header, Payload, and Custom Properties Inspection: View standard JMS-style headers (timestamp, delivery mode, Dead Message Queue eligibility) and examine the message payload alongside any custom properties. This is invaluable for validating data transformations and ensuring message integrity.
  • Message Management: Identify and inspect stuck or problematic messages in queues, with the option to delete them when needed.
  • Purge Queues: Clear all messages from a selected queue in one action, ideal for resetting test environments or clearing backed-up queues during maintenance.

Queue Browser in action

Accessing the Queue Browser

Step 1: Navigate to Queue Monitoring

In the SAP Integration Suite Cockpit, open the left‑hand menu and navigate to:

Monitor › Event Mesh › Queues

Step 2: Review Queue Metrics

You’ll see a comprehensive table listing all your queues with real-time usage metrics:

Monitoring Event Mesh Usage – Queue List Floorplan

  • Name: The name of the queue
  • Messages Queued: Number of messages in the queue
  • Unacknowledged Messages: Number of unacknowledged messages in the queue. Messages delivered but not yet acknowledged as processed.
  • Queue Size: The queue size in bytes.
  • Max Queue Size: The maximum size possible for the queue in bytes.

These metrics provide immediate insight into queue health—high unacknowledged message counts often indicate processing issues, while queues approaching their size limits may need attention.

Step 3: Drill Down to Message List

Message List Report Floorplan

Select any queue to drill down to its message list page, where you can view some per‑message information:

  • Message ID: Identifier for tracking messages
  • Correlation ID: Identifier to trace the request journey
  • Time Sent: Time the message was sent
  • Message Size: The size of the message content, in bytes
  • Redelivered: Indicates if the message was redelivered or not—a key troubleshooting indicator
  • Destination: Destination of the message
  • DMQ Eligible: Indicates whether the message is eligible for the Dead Message Queue (DMQ)

Step 4: Inspect Individual Messages

Message Details – Object Page Floorplan

Click a message entry to navigate to its details page. The level of access depends on your assigned roles:

Users can review the message headers by default; if your BTP user has the EventMeshBusinessExpert role collection assigned, you’ll also see the full payload and any custom properties.

Security Note: Access to single‑message inspection is restricted to specific roles only. Only users assigned the EventMeshBusinessExpert role collection should be granted permission to view full message payloads and custom properties and delete messages. This ensures that message access is tightly controlled per organizational requirements and can be managed via Configuring User Access.

Message Detail Components

Headers Information

  • Identifiers
    • Message ID: Identifier for tracking messages
    • Correlation ID: Identifier to trace the request journey
  • Delivery Information
    • Time Sent: Time the message was sent
    • Redelivered: Indicates if the message was redelivered or not—a key troubleshooting indicator
    • Delivery Mode: The mode which is used for message delivery
  • Routing Information
    • Destination: The destination of the message
    • Reply To: The address or topic to which the recipient should send the response, when a message that requires a reply or acknowledgment, is published.
    • DMQ Eligible: Indicates whether the message is eligible for the Dead Message Queue (DMQ)
  • Additional Information: Message size in bytes

Payload

The message payload contains the actual business data being transmitted between systems.

Custom Properties

Custom properties contain business-specific metadata that applications attach to messages. These might include:

  • Customer IDs for filtering
  • Source system identifiers for tracing

This metadata is invaluable for understanding message context and implementing sophisticated filtering strategies.

Available Actions

From the message detail page, users with appropriate permissions can:

  • Delete individual problematic messages
  • Download message payloads for offline analysis
  • Copy message IDs and correlation IDs for use in other tools

Conclusion

The Queue Browser for Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite transforms how you monitor and troubleshoot event-driven systems. By providing safe, non-disruptive message inspection, it empowers you to validate message content before processing, diagnose complex integration issues, and ensure smooth data flow.

Next Steps

  1. Explore Queue Browser in your SAP Integration Suite tenant—navigate to Monitor › Event Mesh › Queues
  2. Review the official documentation:
    • Monitor Event Mesh
    • Configuring User Access
    • Personas & Permissions
  3. Share your experience on the SAP Community—help others understand how Queue Browser improves their troubleshooting workflows

Queue Browser puts the visibility and control you need right at your fingertips. Start exploring your message queues today and experience the difference that comprehensive message visualization and inspection makes in maintaining event-driven architectures.

Happy monitoring!

entry.title: Purchase Pilot でフリーテキスト発注を AI 変革 — SAP BTP Hackathon 2025 成果レポート
entry.content:
2025 年春、SAP ジャパン の有志メンバーで結成したチーム 「TO BEs」 は、SAP BTP Hackathon 2025 に参加し、 本ハッカソンの公式テーマ「SAP業務にAIでSurpriseを！それ、AIに任せません？」のもと、社内で“もし自分たちが現場でソリューションを構築するとしたら？”というエキシビションとして挑戦しました。

本記事は、その成果として開発した Purchase Pilot の概要と技術アーキテクチャ、およびデモをまとめたレポートです。SAP Community の皆さんからのフィードバックを楽しみにしています！

 

背景 — フリーテキスト発注が生む 3 つの課題

SAP S/4HANA などの購買業務では、品目マスタが存在しない場合に「テキスト発注」が使われます。しかしこの運用には、以下のような問題がつきまといます。

  1. 業務負荷の増大 — 項目を 1 行ずつ入力・確認する手間。
  2. データ品質の低下 — 記述ゆれや入力ミスで KPI が組めない。
  3. 意思決定の遅延 — 精度の低い実績データが経営判断を鈍らせる。

私たちは、この “曖昧で非定型” な領域こそ AI が真価を発揮する余地だと考えました。

 

ソリューション — Purchase Pilot とは？

迷わず・ミスなく・効率的に。

Purchase Pilot は、現場担当者がテキスト発注を入力する際に AI がリアルタイムで支援 するツールです。コア機能は次の 2 つです。

 

仕組み — 2 つのコア機能を深掘り

1. インテリジェントな入力補完 — 処理フロー

ざっくり 3 ステップで完結します。

  1. 過去レコードをベクトルとして準備
    - 過去の正確なテキスト発注レコードを抽出し、Short Text をベクトル化して Vector Engine へ保存。
  2. 類似レコード × Few‑shot
    - マニュアル入力された Short Text をベクトル化し、類似度検索でトップ 3 件を取得。
  3. 意味情報を加えて補完
    - S/4HANA Cloud からコストセンタ名など “意味テキスト” を取得。
    - LLM が Few‑shot とフィールド定義情報を基に各必要項目を推定し、UI 上で提案。

Few‑shot とは、過去レコードを "お手本" として数件渡すことで、LLM により正確な出力を促す手法です。

 

2. リアルタイムな異常検知 — 処理フロー

流れは次の 4 ステップです。

  1. 過去レコードをベクトルとして準備
    - 過去の正確なテキスト発注レコードを抽出し、Short Text をベクトル化して Vector Engine へ保存。
  2. 品目グループ・発注単位を推定
    - マニュアル入力された Short Text をベクトル化し、類似度検索でトップ 3 件を取得。
    - Few‑shot とフィールド定義情報を組み合わせて、LLM が品目グループと発注単位を推定。
  3. レンジを計算
    - 推定した品目グループをキーに S/4HANA Cloud へ問い合わせ、過去レコードから単価・個数レンジを動的に算出。
  4. 異常を判定 & 警告
    - 入力された単価・個数がレンジ外なら即警告。ユーザーは確認モーダル経由で上書き確定も可能。

 

ソリューションアーキテクチャ

* 印はハッカソン時点では未実装のコンポーネントです。

アーキテクチャ図のポイント

  • SAP BTP Cloud Foundry 上に CAP アプリ (Node.js/Python) を配置し、SAP HANA Cloud と SAP AI Core/Gen AI Hub をサービスブローカー経由で統合。
  • Embedding 処理でテキストをベクトル化し、HANA Cloud の Vector Engine に保存・検索。
  • フロントエンドは SAP Build Work Zone にデプロイされた Fiori Elements アプリとして提供。
  • オンプレ SAP S/4HANA とは Cloud Connector で安全にトンネリングし、購買伝票やマスタを連携。（*は PoC では未接続）
  • SAP Cloud Solutions（S/4HANA Cloud, Ariba など）とも同じ OData/SAP BTP 接続モデルで拡張可能。

 

デモ動画 — “5 分入力” が “数十秒” に短縮

動画の流れ

  1. SAP GUI で従来のフリーテキスト発注
    -  マニュアルでのテキスト発注入力は、操作に慣れたユーザでも約 5 分ほどの時間を要し、いくつかの入力ミスが発生します。
  2. Purchase Pilot - 自動補完機能の実演
    - Recommend ボタンをクリックすると、テキストから勘定コード・単位・コストセンタなどを自動補完します。
  3. Purchase Pilot - 異常検知機能の実演
    - 手入力した伝票に対して Validate ボタンを押すと、AI が不足項目や異常値を即時指摘し、修正アドバイスを提示します。

このソリューションにより、入力時間の削減 や 入力ミスの軽減 を実現することができます！また、異常をリアルタイム検知することで、手戻りがゼロ になり、クリーンなデータによる経営指標を高速更新に繋がります！

 

まとめ

  • SAP ジャパン チーム TO BEs の挑戦: 社員視点で “現場 DX” をテーマに、AI × BTP の可能性を検証
  • Purchase Pilot の価値: テキスト発注という "最後の手入力領域" を AI で変革し、操作性とデータ品質を同時に向上。

ご意見をお聞かせください！ コメント欄や SNS でのフィードバックをお待ちしています。

entry.title: How to fix npm error notarget @sap/hdi-deploy when you create a CAP app in BAS
entry.content:
Update (July 2025): Good news — @sap/hdi-deploy@5.5.0 is now available on npm, so this specific error may have disappeared.
But keep reading! The root cause — a dependency pointing to a version that isn’t published yet—can happen again with future releases. The steps below show how to unblock yourself whenever npm throws a notarget error for an @sap/hdi-deploy package.

 

When do you see this error?

1. In SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) click File → New Project from Template.

2. Choose CAP Project and fill in the project name, runtime (Node.js), database (HANA Cloud), etc.

3. Open the terminal and run:

cds add mta   # create files for Cloud Foundry / Kyma deploy
npm i         # install dependencies​

4. npm i stops with this message:

npm error code ETARGET
npm error notarget No matching version found for @sap/hdi-deploy@5.5.0.​

Even if you force "@SAP/hdi-deploy": "5.4.2" in package.json, the error still appears.

 

Why does it happen?

cds add mta adds this line to devDependencies:

"@sap/cds-dk": ">=8"

@SAP/cds-dk version 8.x asks for @SAP/hdi-deploy@5.5.0, but 5.5.0 is not yet published on npm. So npm cannot find it and throws ETARGET.

 

The 3‑line fix

1.  (Optional) clean old modules and cache:

rm -rf node_modules package-lock.json
npm cache clean --force

2. Install the latest cds-dk (today it is 9.1.3):

npm install -D @sap/cds-dk@latest

3. Install the rest:

npm install

cds-dk 9.x points to @sap/hdi-deploy 5.4.2, which exists, so the install succeeds.

 

Example package.json

{
  "scripts": {
    "start": "cds run"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@sap/cds": "^7",
    "@sap/hana-client": "^2",
    "@sap/xssec": "^3"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@sap/cds-dk": "^9.1.3"
  }
}

 

More Information

SAP Community Q&A (same issue): https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/generate-cap-project-in-bas-with-error-sap-hdi-deploy-5-4-2-not-match/qaq-p/14062673

 

Wrap‑up

Next time you hit the @sap/hdi-deploy notarget error, just remember: upgrade @sap/cds-dk and you are done.

If this post helped you, please give Kudos and leave a comment! 🙌

entry.title: Connect & Go: Integration Updates for 2025/1
entry.content:
A seamlessly connected business is more crucial than ever as organizations pursue agility and innovation. Just like the capabilities of SAP Integration Suite that enable you to connect everything in your business, the Connect & Go series brings you a recap of the highlights for the product and how you can get started and integrate with confidence across SAP and non-SAP landscapes.

In the first half of 2025, SAP Integration Suite has delivered new features and enhancements, reaffirming its role as the AI-assisted IPaaS for seamless connectivity, automation, and data-driven decision making. As you dive into this post, you will explore AI updates, expanded capabilities for migration to Integration Suite, latest additions to third-party connectivity and API-centric and event-driven integration. Enjoy!

 

💎AI Updates

SAP Integration Suite introduced a new user experience that empowers developers to use AI capabilities more effectively in their development, configuration, migration, testing, and workload monitoring tasks. This revamped interface aimed to enhance overall productivity and operational excellence, with a consolidated landing page offering a unified view and central activation control for all AI features.

AI-assisted API trends and predictions

Now organizations can leverage AI and machine learning to analyze historical API call volumes and forecast trends and provide insights into traffic patterns.

Deviations from the normal usage or performance in API traffic often indicate security threats, system malfunctions, or other issues that might result in financial loss. This feature addresses this challenge through ML-based anomaly detection, which identifies unusual or abnormal behaviors by continuously monitoring the API traffic. Upon detection of anomalies in API Call Volume, API Error count, and API Response time, the system provides notifications and insights to support investigating the cause and analyzing the impact, as well as recommendations on probable remedial actions. Customers can customize options to select specific API proxies, choose the prediction duration, and set the frequency according to their preferences. With this feature they can proactively adjust their strategies, improving their resilience and competitive edge to maintain the security, reliability, and performance of their APIs. Read more: Leveraging API Traffic Predictions in SAP Integration Suite.

 

📦SAP Business Accelerator Hub News

That the SAP Business Accelerator Hub is the one-stop-shop for pre-built business accelerators you already know. But now, it includes Joule-based discovery and reuse of artifacts to help customers and partners find the right content faster and more intuitively. For an even smoother experience, the hub provides quick access to AI-specific APIs, events, and integrations in a dedicated space. 

And last but not least, the hub now includes a wide range of content for Data Products. Users can explore these products within SAP Business Data Cloud that are built to help businesses manage, analyze, and maximize the value of their data. Offerings include curated datasets, data integration tools, and analytics applications, all designed to support informed, data-driven decision-making.

 

💡 Migration and Modernization

Support of Exactly-Once-In-Order scenario (EOIO)

EOIO is essential in business scenarios where the receiving system requires messages to be received exactly once in the correct order, such as banking operations like deposits and withdrawals, where message order is critical. This functionality supports EOIO via exclusive queues in Cloud Integration and exclusive or partitioned queues using Advance Event Mesh. It ensures no duplicate messages or message loss, as well as the preservation of message sequence during processing.

To learn more about EOIO and how to configure Java Message Service (JMS) adapter, check out New integration flow design guidelines covering Exactly Once In Order pattern, the documentation, and the sample integration flows on SAP Business Accelerator Hub. For AEM, see Exactly once in order (EOIO) for Group messages using Advanced Event Mesh.

Clean Core Modernization Recommendations for IDOCs

New modernization recommendations now include evaluations of different IDOC types in integration scenarios. The respective SOAP/ODATA APIs and Business Events are recommended according to the content on SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Customers can leverage these recommendations during migration to obtain risk and cost reduction when adopting a clean core approach. The additional information is reported in the full evaluation result spreadsheet, learn how to extract the data with a Data Extraction Request or follow the tutorial.

 

🔗Third-party Connectivity

In this first half of 2025 we’ve expanded our ecosystem to help customers integrate across platforms effortlessly. A new set of integration adapters include: IBM MQ (REST, JMS), SAP LeanIX, Google Cloud Storage, Google Pub/Sub, Google BigQuery, Salesforce Pub/Sub, DocuSign, MS 365 Teams, MS 365 OneDrive, Shopify, and more. Additionally, the Remote Function Call (RFC) sender and receiver adapter was made available in Edge Integration Cell to allow direct, on-premise communication with SAP and third-party systems without relying on the SAP Cloud Connector, allowing these systems to initiate RFC calls.

Data Space Integration

The Data Space Integration feature of SAP Integration Suite was made available in Q2 enabling participants within a data space, such as Catena-X, to exchange data with one another in a secure, reliable, and sovereign way. It provides straightforward integration between SAP and non-SAP applications and offers a unified, user-friendly approach to configuring and monitoring data exchanges within the data space, all using the SAP Integration Suite - learn more.

 

🚀API-centric and event-driven integration

Single-source API and events catalog for developers

The API business hub enterprise is now the Developer Hub: a centralized catalog designed for application developers to easily discover, search, and utilize APIs and business events published by their organizations. Customers can benefit from building an extensive company-wide repository of APIs and events, including thorough documentation and code examples, as well as new features like self-registration and analytics. All to empower developers to efficiently integrate various systems and applications. Start exploring: check out how you can Discover S/4HANA Cloud Events in SAP Developer Hub and Enable SAP Developer Hub as central Event Catalog; and read the documentation for APIs and Events. 

 

SAP SuccessFactors events on SAP Business Accelerator Hub​

Explore the new events for SAP SuccessFactors published on SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Stay tuned for more events to come!

Event add-on for SAP ERP and SAP S/4HANA

This add-on for SAP S/4HANA and SAP ECC allows the creation of custom events based on different trigger types. These events can be both notification and data events and allow for loosely coupled, highly scalable, real-time event-driven business architectures powered by SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. Users can easily configure the add-on and create their custom extensible events with or without code, as well as leverage templates for selected events.

Find all relevant details for this exciting update in the blog: The E in Event-Driven Architecture: Introducing SAP’s new Event-Add for ERP.

 

The next edition of Connect & Go is scheduled for September/October 2025. Until then:

- Stay informed | Read the Related Updates:

  • Generative AI-based script optimization – Q1 25
  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub domains take centerstage – Q1 25
  • New Partner Content on SAP Business Accelerator Hub - Q2 25
  • Integration Advisor – multi-payload support for MIG creation - Q3 25
  • Update Version of an Integration Flow Component - Q3 25
  • Partner Directory Accelerator Tool for Pipeline Concept  – Q3 25

- Stay in Touch:

  • Join the monthly update webinars 
  • Interact in the Integration group
  • Subscribe to the Newsletter

entry.title: Expanding Data Federation for Broader Coverage with the New Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Related Blogs:
  • Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud

SAP HANA smart data access (SDA) has played a pivotal role in data federation, serving as a cornerstone for positioning SAP HANA Cloud as a single gateway to all data. As highlighted in my previous blog, Taking Data Federation to the Next Level: Accessing Remote ABAP CDS View Entities in SAP HANA Cloud, SDA has also established itself as the core component for leveraging the full potential of data in the context of Clean Core.

Nevertheless, due to its limited protocol boundary to ODBC and REST, along with restrictions on running third-party drivers within the SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud, the supported scope of remote sources has been limited in SAP HANA Cloud.

This limitation has been complemented by SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI) through its JDBC-based adapters, as it also supports data federation, even though SDI is primarily designed for real-time data replication. However, customers must deploy and operate Data Provisioning Agent (DPAgent) separately in an on-premise setup.

In this context, I'm pleased to announce that, starting with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, SDA now supports Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake as two new remote sources via a new Data Access Agent. This new Data Access Agent expands data federation and provides broader coverage with JDBC-based adapters as an SAP-managed service.

In a nutshell, the new Data Access Agent was developed with the following three key characteristics.

  • Fully managed and secure: Like the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, this new Data Access Agent can be provisioned and deprovisioned in SAP HANA Cloud Central or via the Cloud Foundry Command Line Interface (cf CLI), but it operates separately. This separation helps ensure the SAP HANA database remains secure, as the Data Access Agent runs as a physically separate instance.
  • Greater flexibility: While the natively available SDA adapters continue to be based on ODBC and REST, this new Data Access Agent supports JDBC-based adapters. These will allow leveraging not only existing SDI adapters but also new third-party driver-based adapters.
  • Simplified operations: As this new Data Access Agent is managed by SAP in a cloud-native manner, the configuration and monitoring processes have become significantly more streamlined and user-friendly.

The good news is that support for remote sources to Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning. As described, since this new Data Access Agent introduces new possibilities for connecting to remote sources with different protocols, there are plans to support additional remote sources for data federation, including SharePoint in Microsoft 365, Google Sheets, and more.

However, please note that although this new Data Access Agent supports new JDBC-based adapters, it only supports data federation and snapshot replica toggling within the virtual table interface. That is, trigger-based real-time replication, like SDI, is not supported.
  

Getting Started with Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud

The first step to configuring remote source connections with the Data Access Agent is to ensure that the BTP subaccount is entitled to the service plan hana-data-access-agent. This is a prerequisite for using the Data Access Agent.

 

Create Data Access Agent:

If the service plan is correctly entitled, you can view and use the new Data Access Agent menu in the multi-environment edition of SAP HANA Cloud Central.

Now, you can proceed with the Create Data Access Agent button to provision a new Data Access Agent by entering its name and selecting one of the four preset size options.

The size of the Data Access Agent will depend on the workloads, and its capacity units (CUs) consumption will vary based on the selected size.

Please refer to the links below for further details, including sizing guidelines. Additionally, you can use the SAP HANA Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator (to be updated soon) to simulate the expected cost of a Data Access Agent for each size and monthly activity, even though the total estimate is already displayed on the right side of the above screen.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Setting Up the Data Access Agent

Once the name and size are decided, the next step is to register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud.

To register the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, the corresponding SAP HANA database must be up and running. Additionally, the Data Provisioning Server must be enabled as a prerequisite. Another prerequisite is that the version of the SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud must be QRC 02/2025 or later.

Otherwise, it cannot be selected or registered. The reason for being unable to register is also shown in the Details column.

Another important consideration is that a single Data Access Agent can only be registered to one SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. Once registered, the registration cannot be changed to a different SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. This means that for another SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud, a new Data Access Agent must be created from scratch. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents, if needed.

After selecting the SAP HANA database instance to register, the next step is to enable adapters to access remote sources.

In the first release of the Data Access Agent, two adapters are available, as mentioned above. One is the AzureSQL adapter, which is used for accessing the Microsoft Azure SQL Database. The other is the Snowflake adapter, which is used for accessing Snowflake.

Adapters can be enabled or disabled later, even after the creation of the Data Access Agent. As previously mentioned, many more adapters will become available in the future.

Alright, that’s all for creating or provisioning a Data Access Agent.

Once the Data Access Agent is up and running, everything is set for creating remote sources and virtual tables. This process is not new and is essentially the same as using SAP HANA Smart Data Access (SDA) or SAP HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI).
 

Create a remote source:

-- create a remote source to Snowflake
CREATE REMOTE SOURCE "Snowflake" ADAPTER "Snowflake"
AT LOCATION AGENT GROUP "demo-daa"
CONFIGURATION 'url=https://<myorganization-myaccount>.snowflakecomputing.com;
database=<database_name>;account=<account_name>;auth_type=Password'
WITH CREDENTIAL TYPE 'PASSWORD' USING 'user=<user_name>;password=<password>';

The above example shows how to create a remote source for Snowflake using the CREATE REMOTE SOURCE statement.

Similar to other SDA or SDI remote sources, it can be created using the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI, and remote objects can be retrieved.

Since the syntax and parameters for creating a remote source vary depending on the remote source, please refer to the links below for further details.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create an Azure SQL Remote Source
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Snowflake Remote Source
     

Create virtual tables:

Once the remote source is created, virtual tables can be created using either the CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE statement or the SAP HANA Database Explorer UI.

However, since creating virtual tables and generating statistics are essentially the same as with other SDA adapters, I will not cover these topics in this blog. Please refer to my previous blog or the links below for more information.

  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create a Virtual Table
  • SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Data Access Guide: Create Statistics on a Virtual Table or Linked Database
     

FAQs

Q: Do you have plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent, similar to SDI? If so, will SDA replace SDI?
A: No, there are no concrete plans to support real-time data replication with the Data Access Agent. As described, the Data Access Agent is intended only for data federation.

Q: It sounds like this new Data Access Agent is a cloud version of DPAgent. Is that the right understanding?
A: The new Data Access Agent can, to some extent, be logically regarded as a cloud version of DPAgent, but it is solely for data federation, as explained. It has been adapted and enhanced to support completely new remote sources, such as Snowflake. Furthermore, support for SharePoint in Microsoft 365 (e.g., list and Excel worksheet), Google Sheets, and more will follow. These remote sources have never been supported via SDI and DPAgent, although SharePoint has been supported for specific formats, such as CSV.

Q: It seems that with SAP HANA Cloud QRC 02/2025, two new adapters can be enabled with the Data Access Agent. Does enabling an adapter incur additional costs?
A: No, enabling adapters does not incur any additional cost. In other words, regardless of how many new remote resources SAP supports by introducing new adapters via the Data Access Agent in the future, they will not incur any additional cost. Customers only need to pay for running the Data Access Agent itself.
However, the recommended number of adapters may vary depending on the size of the Data Access Agent. To ensure performance and efficient resource utilization, we plan to provide guidance or impose restrictions on the maximum number of adapters based on the size of the Data Access Agent if more adapters are introduced in the future.

Q: What will happen to the existing native ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters? Will they be discontinued or replaced with the new Data Access Agent-based adapters?
A: No, the existing native built-in ODBC and REST-based SDA adapters will continue, and even new remote source support can be introduced as a native built-in ODBC or REST-based SDA adapter. SAP will choose the best protocol when introducing support for a new remote source for data federation. In other words, newer remote sources can be supported either natively (via ODBC or REST) or through the Data Access Agent (via JDBC).

Q: Do you have plans to support the same capability (e.g., the Snowflake adapter via Data Access Agent) with SAP HANA Platform 2.0? Or can I register this new Data Access Agent with SAP HANA Platform 2.0?
A: No, these features are exclusive to SAP HANA database of SAP HANA Cloud.

Q: Can I use a single Data Access Agent with multiple SAP HANA databases in SAP HANA Cloud?
A: No, as already explained, a single Data Access Agent can only be registered with a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud. However, a single SAP HANA database in SAP HANA Cloud can have multiple Data Access Agents.
 

Conclusion

In summary, the newly developed Data Access Agent in SAP HANA Cloud significantly enhances secure, flexible, and simplified access to remote data sources in a cloud-native manner. Its fully managed, physically separate service ensures the security of the SAP HANA database while supporting seamless provisioning and operation. With protocol flexibility, including JDBC-based adapter support, it enables integration with both existing SDI adapters and new third-party drivers. Its cloud-native design also simplifies configuration and monitoring, reducing complexity for users.

Support for Microsoft Azure SQL Database and Snowflake is just the beginning, with plans to expand to additional remote sources like SharePoint in Microsoft 365 and Google Sheets, further broadening data federation capabilities. However, it is important to note that this new capability focuses on data federation and snapshot replica toggling and does not support trigger-based real-time replication, as SDI does.

This innovation reaffirms SAP’s commitment to enhancing data integration while simplifying cloud-based processes, paving the way for more robust and dynamic data connectivity.

entry.title: Selective Data Transition using SAP Business Transformation Center (BTC)
entry.content:
Selective Data Transition- Overview

As part of the SDT Proces, an SAP ERP Shell System must be created and converted to an SAP S/4HANA Shell System.
 

The conversion follows a structured approach:
 
1️. Shell System Creation
A shell copy of the SAP ECC system is created.
This copy excludes transactional and master data while preserving configurations and repository objects.
SAP Standard Tool-based methods (e.g., System & Client Copy, Landscape Transformation) or SAP Partner Services can be used.
 
2️. SAP S/4HANA Conversion
The ECC Shell System undergoes a technical conversion to SAP S/4HANA, ensuring it is ready to receive selectively migration data.

3️. Selective Data Transition with BTC
The SAP Business Transformation Center analyzes the Source system data using readiness check report and defines which company codes, transformation objects, and historical data should be migrated.
The Digital Blueprint is generated, documenting all scoped data for a controlled migration.
Data transformation is executed within SAP BTC, ensuring a structured transition from SAP ECC to SAP S/4HANA

 

 

 

 

STEP 1- Shell Creation using LT Cockpit with System Copy Concept

Before we talk about shell creation process, let us see what is the shell system ?

Shell is the system with reduced data volume excluding application data and unnecessary clients.

The shell creation process excludes all clients except the SAP reference client 000, which is fully copied to the target system, including all data such as user master records, cross-client customizing, and Repository data[ including reports, programs, and table structures for all database tables]

The Shell system does not contain the following types of data:

  • Business Client-specific Customizing data
  • Business Client-specific Application data

Shell Creation Procedure

Step (i): Create an Empty Shell System

  • Use the SAP System Copy procedure via Software Provisioning Manager (SWPM).
  • Utilize SAP Landscape Transformation Cockpit (SAP LT Cockpit) to exclude transactional and Master data.
  • Copy only repository objects, cross-client customizing data, and client 000.
  • Ensure the target system is properly installed and configured.

Step (ii): Perform the Client Copy

  • Create and RFC connection from Target system to Source System.
  • Use Transaction SCCL (Local Client Copy) or SCC9 (Remote Client Copy).
  • Select the appropriate profile (e.g., SAP_UCSV).
  • Validate the copy process by checking logs (SCC3).

 

Shell Creation Execution Steps

Task 1: Setting of ENV variables for shell creation. 

Task 2: Export Preparation  using SWPM

Task  3: Table splitting [If required] using SWPM

Task 4: Shell creation process using the LT Cockpit

Task 5: DB instance export and import using SWPM

Task 6: Perform the  Client Copy using the profile SAP_UCSV

 

Task 1:Setting of ENV variables for shell creation. 

         we have to set the below environmental variables as root user at OS level during the DB Export Preparation , Table splitting operation and DB instance export

              export SAP_LT_SHELL_CREATION= TRUE

 

Task  2: Export Preparation using SWPM

During the Export preparation it performs the below

1.Creates the Export structure

Directory

 Description

<export dump dir>/DATA

Contains the STR files generated by R3ldctl

<export dump dir>/DB

Contains the DDL<DBTYPE>.TPL files generated by R3ldctl

<export dump dir>/DB/<DBTYPE>

Contains the EXT files generated by R3szchk (optional)

2.Upon creation of the export structure , it used R3LDCTL, R3SZCHK to create STR and TPL Files

R3LDCTL

                a. Creates the *.STR file [Structure files] which are Database Independent [STR Files have characteristics of all the tables/indexes as specified in SAP data dictionary]

               b. Creates the *.TPL files [Template files] which are database dependent [TPL Files contain the database specific syntax for creating the tables and indexes ]

R3SZCHK

  1. Calculates the size of the ABAP and indexes tables and creates the *.EXT Files.

 

R3LDCTL retrieves information from the DD09L table, extracts the size category and data class information of the respective table information, and update this data in .STR files.

R3LDCTL gathers information from TA<DBS> and IA<DBS> to determine which data class is assigned to which storage unit and records this information in DDL<DBS>.TPL files.

 

Task 3: Table splitting using SWPM

As this System copy process is part of shell creation , so we are able to perform the table splitting for cross client tables only

For example DBTABLOG is a cross client table, so it eligible to perform the Table splitting

So to check whether the table is cross client or not you can follow the below steps

1.Check the table DD02L which contains metadata

2.Check the filed name CLNTDEPEND

                     if Filed value is “c” then it is Client dependent table

                     if Filed value is “ “[blank] then it is client independent table

SAPUptool tool will perform the Table splitting operation

Export preparation with table split operation, generates a file WHR.txt with names of the related tables and

.WHR files with the WHERE Conditions for the table split.

Note:  If you try to perform the table split operation for Client specific tables it will through an error

during the shell creation process in LT Cockpit

 

Task 4: Shell Creation Process using Landscape Transformation Cockpit

Mandatory Pre requisite for Shell creation  ------ Make sure DMIS Add on installed[DMIS 2011]

    1.Login to SAP Source system with client 000 and give the T code : CNV_MBT_SLOP

                    a. Create the Project and sub project

                    b. Create the package :Shell Creation for ERP

2. Once Package is created for Shell creation, execute the below task list, where below task list creates the background jobs to perform an action. We can monitor in  T code Sm37

 

 

Task 5: DB Instance Export and Import

During the export and import , R3LOAD is responsible for Export and import of data from the Database

DB instance Export 

During the export operation, R3LOAD uses the files created by the R3ldctl and R3szchk and creates the below

  1. a. Compressed binary format files .001, .002 etc..,
  2. b. TOC files[Table of Content]
  3. c.  TSK files [Task files]

DB instance Import

During the import operation, R3load uses the  STR files to create the database objects and uses the dump files to populate the target database

Task 6: perform the Remote Client Copy using the profile SAP_UCSV

 

Important Files To Check For Troubleshooting

During the Export operation we have to check the below log files as part of trouble shooting

  • Export_monitor_cmd.properties
  • Export_state.properties
  • ExportMonitor.console.log

 

During the import operation we have to check the below log files as part of trouble shooting

  • Import _monitor_cmd.properties
  • Import_state.properties
  • ImportMonitor.console.log

Location for the below log files

During export operation \tmp\sapinst_instdir\NW<version>\<Database name>\COPY\EXP\AS-ABAP

Ex: if it is Oracle with sap NW version 752-- cd \tmp\sapinst_instdir\NW752\ORA\COPY\EXP\AS-ABAP

During import operation \tmp\sapinst_instdir\NW<version>\<Database name>\COPY\EXP\AS-ABAP

Ex: if it is HANA  /tmp/sapinst_instdir/GENERIC/HDB/DBREFRESH

 

STEP 2-- S4 SYSTEM CONVERSION 

 

STEP 3 -- Selective Data Transition with BTC

Below are the High level steps as part of data selection 

  • STEP 1:  Generating the analysis file from the source system by implementing the SAP NOTES  SAP Note 3112362 & SAP Note 3275056
  • STEP 2: Uploading the source data zip file from STEP 1 to SAP BTC.
  • STEP 3: Creating a digital blueprint out of the uploaded file
  • STEP 4: Understanding the source system data through 'Select Company Code' App
  • STEP 5: Scoping company code and Transformation objects for selective data transitioning
  • STEP 6: Scoping custom Z-objects and data from bespoke application for migration
  • STEP 7: Scoping the scanned tables
  • STEP 8: Confirming the Digital Blue Print
  • STEP 9: Creating a Transformation model for project execution
  • STEP 10: Connect the source ECC System and Target Converted Empty Shell system using Cloud Connector.
  • STEP 11: Feeding this information into the S/4 HANA converted SHELL system.
  • STEP 12: Data migration to target S/4 HANA

 

BTC Integration with Source and Target systems

BTC Connectivity Diagram From Source ECC To Target S4

SAP Business Transformation Center is a cloud native application which relies on the following components:

  • The source system, which utilizes the current ST-PI add-on to enable the data transformation with SAP Business Transformation Center.
  • The SAP S/4HANA system, which contains all necessary subcomponents already shipped within theSAP S/4HANA CORE component.

Each system is accessed from the cloud layer using the SAP Cloud Connector.

The SAP ECC system and the SAP S/4HANA system are connected via OData service bindings from SAP Business Technology Platform.

There is an RFC-based connection between the SAP ECC and the SAP S/4HANA system.

Connectivity Steps From Source ECC to BTC

High level tasks involved with onboarding a new SAP ECC source system to SAP BTC:

1.Ensure that the minimum version requirement as described in question 'What are the restrictions in using BTC for SDT?'  is met.

2.Ensure to apply the SAP note 3443741 in source system.

3.Configure the required OData services in the ABAP source system for SAP Business Transformation Center as described in OData Services .

4.Configure Cloud Connector for the source system in SAP Business Transformation Center as described in Configure Cloud Connector 

5.Connect the ABAP system to cloud ALM using the 'Landscape management' app as described in Connect an ABAP System to SAP Cloud ALM 

6.Maintain the property store in source ECC via the /BDTS/ADMIN transaction as described in Property Store in SAP ECC System 

 

Connectivity Steps From Target S4 To BTC

High level tasks involved with onboarding a target S/4 HANA Shell to SAP BTC:

1.Ensure that the minimum version requirement as described in question for target 'What are the restrictions in using BTC for SDT?'  is met.

2.Ensure to apply the SAP note 3443741 in target system.

  1.  Configure the OData services in the ABAP target system for SAP Business Transformation Center as described in Target OData services 

4.Configure Cloud Connector for the target system in SAP Business Transformation Center as described in Cloud Connector 

5.Connect an ABAP System to SAP Cloud ALM as described in Connect target to Cloud ALM .

6.Create RFC Destination to SAP ECC Source System in target system and maintain the property store in target as described in Maintenance of Property Store in SAP S/4HANA System . This RFC will be used by the migration engine of SAP BTC to pull data packages from the SAP ECC source system  and hence must be maintained in the property RfcDestinationSender in t-code bdts_admin-> Select BDTS_PROPERTIES_SET. Also refer to SAP note 3477261 - SAP Business Transformation Center: Troubleshooting - Setup and Configuration .

7.During the shell conversion process, the upgrade buffer of the system was updated and this must be saved as described in the link Save the Upgrade Buffers .

8.To enable the handling of cloud commands on the ABAP side, the Command Daemon must be  activated as described in Start the Command Daemon 

 

Reference documents

Shell Creation for SAP ERP | SAP Help Portal

Selective Data Transition Engagement (sap.com)

Move to SAP S/4HANA with Selective Data Transition - SAP Community

Troubleshooting for Migration to SAP HANA | SAP Help Portal

Everything about using SAP Business Transformation... - SAP Community

entry.title: Where can I learn how to administrate SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Administrating SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud, Universal Model learning journey.

Overview
This course is designed to equip participants with the skills necessary to effectively manage and administer SAP's Profitability and Performance Management Cloud using the Universal Model. This training provides a comprehensive understanding of the subscription process, role management, team restrictions, authorization, event logs, connection setups, and administration applications within the SAP Business Technology Platform. Participants will learn to navigate the complexities of SAP PaPM Cloud, ensuring efficient data management, security, and performance optimization.

Learning Objectives
  • Understand the subscription process and activation of the Universal Model in SAP Business Technology Platform.
  • Manage SAP Business Technology Platform roles and restrict application access based on client needs.

Prerequisites

  • Exploring Foundations of SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud, Universal Model
    Modeling in SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud, Universal Model 

Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 
Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! 
We are here to support you.


I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.

Kind regards
Margit

entry.title: Inside SAP Series Mid-Year Wrap-Up: Powered by Practice, Driven by Data
entry.content:
As we head into the summer break, it’s the perfect time to reflect on what we’ve explored so far in this year’s Inside SAP series. Designed to give an inside look into how SAP’s IT organization drives innovation from within, the series features experts from across CPIT sharing real-world insights into how we use our own technology to transform the enterprise.

We opened the 2025 season with a clear message: transformation starts at home. In the first session, Oliver Gutzeit took us behind the scenes of SAP’s digital landscape, demonstrating how we bring together AI, data, processes, and applications to create real business impact.

The following three sessions focused on one of the most powerful enablers of that transformation: data. We explored how SAP is shaping a modern data architecture strategy to fuel both AI innovation and smarter decision-making. From building semantically rich data products, to scaling data and machine learning capabilities, to enabling broader access through data democratization efforts, the series offered valuable insights into how data is evolving into a strategic asset throughout SAP.

The importance of easy to consume and available data, as well as the mind shift needed to achieve this, were part of the session delivered by Oliver Huth, Head of Platform – SAP Enterprise Analytics. He captured the idea with the following analogy and visual illustration:

“We only create a data product if there's a need—just like a coke drink in the supermarket: it has to be well-placed, accessible, easy to consume, and trustworthy. You should be able to pick it up, use it immediately, and even combine it with others—because the real value comes when data products are interoperable and share the same semantics.”

Each session highlighted how SAP IT is applying these technologies internally, turning strategy into practice and challenges into scalable solutions.

Looking ahead, the second half of the series will shift its focus to AI. Resuming with the series in September, we’ll dive into how SAP is accelerating insights and transforming analytics through AI-powered capabilities. You’ll hear how data and intelligence come together to deliver value across the business, and how we’re transforming user experiences with natural language and automation. The series will then explore further topics such as financial planning, process mining as well as SAP’s own sales transformation, all with the goal to share our insights and lessons learned and to inspire our customers on their journey to bring out their best.

Until then, you can catch up on past sessions and register for the upcoming ones on the event page.

Enjoy the summer and, we look forward to continuing the journey with you soon!

entry.title: How to evaluate an idea of custom AI scenario for your business system like SAP S/4HANA Cloud in AI
entry.content:
SAP Business AI has listed all the  pre-delivered AI Scenarios for our business systems like SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Which means once we finished the initial setup like Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide, our end users can use the pre-delivered AI Scenarios.

In some situations, our business systems' users and other associates have some genius ideas to use LLM in the system. Then how to quickly evaluate the idea and the Effect of the idea? Give an example, in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Outbound Delivery documents are create again Sales Orders, then the routes are  determined based on route determination logic. Are there any better options? For example, can we ask LLM to give some suggestions on routes based on more information like destinations' weather forecast, or even based on some freight charge information as grounding? I don't know yet. But I can quickly evaluate my idea With SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad before the developer starts to develop. 

Prerequisites:

  • SAP AI Core has been initially set up in your BTP Sub Account.
  • SAP AI Launchpad has been initially set up in your BTP Sub Account.

Steps:

1.  Prepare the data which can fetched from release API or  CDS View.  I have prepared data as the following:
{
    "DeliveryDocument": "80000000",
    "HeaderGrossWeight": "3.000",
    "HeaderNetWeight": "2.700",
    "HeaderWeightUnit": "KG",
    "HeaderVolume": "0.000",
    "HeaderVolumeUnit": "",
    "ShipFromAddress": { //from shop point address
        "CityName": "Palo Alto",
        "CompanyPostalCode": "",
        "CorrespondenceLanguage": "EN",
        "Country": "US",
        "EmailAddress": "",
        "FaxNumber": "",
        "FaxNumberExtension": "",
        "Floor": "",
        "FormOfAddress": "0003",
        "HomeCityName": "",
        "HouseNumber": "3475",
        "HouseNumberSupplementText": "",
        "MobilePhoneNumber": "",
        "PhoneNumber": "",
        "PostalCode": "94304-1355",
        "PrfrdCommMediumType": "",
        "Region": "CA",
        "RoomNumber": "",
        "StreetName": "Deer Creek",
        "StreetPrefixName": "",
        "StreetSuffixName": "",
        "TaxJurisdiction": "GA00000000"
    },
        "ShipToAddress": {   //from ship to party address
        "DeliveryDocument": "80000000",
        "PartnerFunction": "SP",
        "AddressID": "22900",
        "BusinessPartnerName1": "Domestic US Customer 1",
        "AddressTimeZone": "EST",
        "CityName": "Atlanta",
        "CompanyPostalCode": "",
        "CorrespondenceLanguage": "EN",
        "Country": "US",
        "EmailAddress": "mrinal.kanti.chanda@sap.com",
        "FaxNumber": "",
        "FaxNumberExtension": "",
        "Floor": "",
        "FormOfAddress": "0003",
        "HomeCityName": "",
        "HouseNumber": "200",
        "HouseNumberSupplementText": "",
        "MobilePhoneNumber": "",
        "PhoneNumber": "999 555 6721",
        "PostalCode": "30315-1402",
        "PrfrdCommMediumType": "",
        "Region": "GA",
        "RoomNumber": "",
        "StreetName": "Augusta Ave SE",
        "StreetPrefixName": "",
        "StreetSuffixName": "",
        "TaxJurisdiction": "GA00000000"
    }
}

 

2.  Test in SAP AI Launchpad:

I prepared the follow Sytem prompt:

You are an expert of logistic.You have received a user's outbound delivery information in JSON. The user need you to suggest a best route based outbound delivery JSON information.

 The User Prompt is the JSON file in Step 1 .

Let's test in SAP AI Launchpad with GPT-4.1.

The following is the response from GPT-4.1

Based on your outbound delivery JSON, here’s your **delivery scenario**:

- **Ship From:** 3475 Deer Creek, Palo Alto, CA 94304-1355
- **Ship To:** 200 Augusta Ave SE, Atlanta, GA 30315-1402
- **Weight:** 3.0 kg (Net: 2.7 kg)
- **Country:** US (Domestic shipment)
- **Time Zone Difference:** Palo Alto (Pacific) → Atlanta (Eastern)
- **No special volume requirement or hazardous cargo flagged**

---

## Best Route Suggestion

### 1. **Route Options Overview**

#### **A. Air Freight**
- **Best for:** Speed (overnight or 1-2 day delivery)
- **Cost:** Highest (but the shipment weight is low, so the cost is manageable)
- **Process:**
  - Pickup from Palo Alto
  - Deliver to SFO, OAK, or SJC airport
  - Direct flight to ATL
  - Local delivery in Atlanta

#### **B. Ground Courier (Expedited)**
- **Best for:** Fast and reliable ground service (2-3 days typical with express)
- **Carriers:** FedEx, UPS, USPS Priority Express, DHL
- **Cost:** Lower than air freight, still fast for lightweight parcels

#### **C. Ground Courier (Standard)**
- **Best for:** Cost efficiency, less urgency (4-6 days)
- **Carriers:** FedEx Ground, UPS Ground, USPS Priority

---

### 2. **Recommended (Best) Route for Your Delivery**

Given your shipment details (very light, no hazardous/volume concerns), and typical business shipping needs:

#### **FedEx/UPS/DHL Express Air Service**
1. **Pickup:** Arrange for parcel pickup at 3475 Deer Creek, Palo Alto, CA.
2. **Transport:** 
   - Collected and sent same day to a regional hub (San Francisco/Oakland/San Jose for air departure).
   - Overnight air transport to Atlanta Hartsfield International Airport.
3. **Delivery:** 
   - Early-morning or same-day handoff for final-mile delivery in Atlanta.
   - Will reach consignee at 200 Augusta Ave SE, Atlanta, within 24-36 hours.

**Features:**
- **Tracking & Signature**: Included.
- **Best for:** Business-critical, customer satisfaction.
- **Estimated Delivery Time:** Next business day or 2 business days.
- **Estimated Cost:** Moderate (due to low parcel weight).

---

### 3. **Alternative: Ground Courier Service**

If premium speed is not critical:

- **FedEx Ground, UPS Ground, or USPS Priority Mail**
