- Delivery estimate: 4-6 business days
- Pickup same as above, direct line haul across the US
- Cost: Lower

---

## **Suggested Carrier and Service**

- **Carrier:** FedEx, UPS, or DHL Express (all ideal for coast-to-coast shipments)
- **Service:** FedEx Priority Overnight, UPS Next Day Air Saver, or DHL Express Worldwide
- **Booking:** You can book online, arrange for pickup, label your parcel at origin. Given the low weight, most shipping managers select air express for coast-to-coast in the US.

---

### **Route Mapping Summary**

```
1. Palo Alto, CA (your facility)
      ↓
2. SFO/SJC/OAK Airport (CA hub, air transfer)
      ↓
3. ATL Airport (GA hub, air arrival)
      ↓
4. Atlanta last-mile depot
      ↓
5. 200 Augusta Ave SE, Atlanta, GA (customer)
```

---

## **Action Steps**
- Package and label your shipment.
- Get quotes from FedEx, UPS, DHL online or through your logistics provider for **air express service**.
- Book for next day pickup/drop-off.
- Share tracking with your customer.

**Note:** If your delivery is not time-critical or if budget is the priority, use a ground service instead, accepting the longer transit time.

---

**Do you need carrier recommendations, rate estimation, or step-by-step booking guidance?** Let me know how I can specifically assist next!

Of course, you can adjust the prompt or even you grounding some document information in AI Launchpad.

If the result is acceptable, then Architecture can design. Then the developer can start to realize back end with CAP NodeJS, CAP Java, RAP(Cloud ABAP), Python. The listed Languages are supported by the SAP AI SDK.

The end!

Thanks for your time!

Jacky Liu

entry.title: Using List of Values in Document AI to classify documents and other validation tasks
entry.content:
Document AI (also known as Document Information Extraction previously) helps you to process large number of business documents of various layouts.

With the advancement of Generative AI and LLM, Document AI can now process various document types and more complex documents. Thanks to the support for list of values data type, it's more versatile than you might expect.

Let’s take a quick tour of what’s possible — and maybe spark some ideas for your next project.

Prerequisites:

  • Subscription to Document AI (Premium Edition)

 

Document Classification

Let’s say you’ve got a stack of documents — invoices, contracts, shipping receipts, and tax forms. Normally, sorting them would take hours.

With Document AI and natural language prompting, you can now say:

“Classify this document as one of: [‘CertificateOfCompliance’, ‘DeliveryOrder’, ServiceReport']”

The clearer the prompts, the better the results.

The following shows an example of a schema that used list of values to classify documents.

 

 

 

 

 

 

You can add a total of 20 values here for this data type.

 

Extension

I applied Document AI’s list of values feature to detect the presence of signatures within documents. While signature detection wasn’t the primary objective, leveraging this approach helps automate a key part of document validation.

The example below uses list of values to determine if there’s a signature.

 

To bring everything together, I created a custom schema that performs two key tasks: detecting the presence of a signature and classifying the document type. For this demonstration, I used a sample Certificate of Compliance. The model successfully identified that a signature was present and classified the document as a Certificate of Compliance. The output below illustrates the results.

 

Now Supports More Languages!

A major upgrade to Document AI is its expanding multilingual support. Now, you can extract, classify, and analyze documents written not just in English, but also in languages like Malay, Spanish, French, Japanese, and more.

 

In this post, I introduced how to leverage Document AI’s list of values feature to enhance your projects. . While signature detection wasn’t the primary objective, this use case highlights the flexibility and potential of combining structured schemas with prompting. There’s plenty of room to expand on this approach for more advanced document processing tasks.

 

See also:

  • Tutorials:
    • Setup BTP Trial Account
    • Setup Document AI in BTP Trial Account
  • List of values data type
  • Supported Languages

entry.title: Anna Hartmann
entry.content:
Anna

  • Germany
  • SAP Mentor since 2025
  • Follow Anna on LinkedIn

Anna is managing director at in4MD Service GmbH. Her journey began with mastering ABAP programming from 2010 to 2013. By 2013, Anna was deeply involved in the HANA environment, managing around 100 databases and developing teaching materials covering areas such as Predictive Analysis Library, Geospatial, Text Mining, Fiori development on HANA, and Smart Data Integration for the SAP University Alliance Program in the SAP University Competence Center Magdeburg. This extensive engagement has equipped her with an in-depth knowledge of the entire HANA platform, both 1.0 and 2.0. Anna is also one of the authors of the SAP Press book "SAP HANA – Datenbankadministration" (ISBN 978-3-8362-6850-9).

Topics of interest: HANA database, HANA Cloud, SAP landscape and architecture, ABAP, BTP

Marla, what inspired you to become an SAP Mentor?

What drives Anna is ensuring the needs of mid-sized customers are met, as they often feel overlooked by SAP. Anna is passionate about being their voice, representing their interests whether through on-premise solutions, cloud (Azure, Google), or RISE and GROW projects. Her diverse background and commitment to these clients makes her an ideal candidate for the SAP Mentor Program, where I can advocate effectively for this crucial segment of the SAP community. Anna also has a broad network within the technical SAP community thanks to the many years of involvement in DSAG.

What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

Get involved into the SAP community, it's a great opportunity to learn from others and gain different perspectives. Stay curious and continuously learn about new SAP technologies and best practices. Network actively with other SAP professionals to share insights and solve challenges together. Always keep the core business processes of your company or customer in mind to deliver real value with your technical solutions.

entry.title: News from SAP Activate SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and more
entry.content:
We are pleased to announce the availability of the updates to SAP Activate and share exciting news – the launch of Joule in SAP Activate road map viewer – for customers, partners, and SAP internal users. We are also excited about the new visual design of the home page in the road map viewer and the updated user experience. This release introduces several exciting updates to the implementation guidance across a range of SAP Activate assets. We continue to aim to streamline and improve the implementation process, providing a more seamless experience for our valued users. Here are the key highlights for this release:

  • NEW - Enhance Your SAP Activate road map viewer Experience with Joule
  • Revamped Visual Design for the SAP Activate road map viewer
  • NEW - SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages
  • SAP Activate Community Blogs and Activate Minute Videos
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform
  • Updates to SAP Activate for Conversion of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2-system to 3-system landscape
  • Updates to SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool 2508 Release

Enhance Your SAP Activate road map viewer Experience with Joule

We are thrilled to share that Joule is now generally available in the SAP Activate road map viewer. With Joule, customers, partners and SAP internal users can quickly ask Activate related questions and receive clear, helpful answers – making it easier to unlock the full value of SAP Activate.

Joule is available to all SAP for Me users and currently supports two of our most widely used road maps:

  • SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private – New Implementation
  • SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape)

To learn more about how to interact with Joule, check out the blog post here.

 

Revamped Visual Design for the SAP Activate road map viewer

We’ve enhanced the onboarding experience for new users of the SAP Activate road map viewer by introducing a fresh visual design, updated guidance, and built-in onboarding resources right on the home screen. Learn more about these improvements in this blog post. 

 

NEW SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages

We’re excited to announce the release of a dedicated SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages. This new resources is now available to customers in the road map viewer, and you can find more details in the blog post here.

 

SAP Activate Community | SAP Activate Blogs | SAP Activate Minute Videos

Join the SAP Activate Community to explore valuable content and resources while connecting with SAP partners, clients and internal colleagues by participating in discussions and sharing knowledge.

Make sure to follow the SAP Activate tag to access blog posts like those highlighted here, along with additional insights shared by SAP Activate experts within the community.

Recap of some blog posts from the community:

  • New Road Maps for SAP Business Network - Supplier Portal Private Edition and Commerce Automation by Ana Goetze
  • Key Enhancements to the SAP Fieldglass Road map by Ana Goetze
  • Learn Quickly via the SAP Activate Minute Videos by Dan Ciecko
  • Planning your System Conversion to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition following SAP Activate by Jose Marquez Mares
  • Security, Data Protection and IAM guidelines in SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition by Kiran Bose
  • Accelerating Implementation with SAP Activate in the Public Cloud by user pranavgarud
  • Guiding Your Cloud Journey: The New SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Adoption Plan Roadmap by Christina Galbreath
  • Unlocking Innovation: Understanding SAP’s Clean Core and Its Benefits (for IT Leaders) by user arpin
  • Explore the SAP Activate Methodology using a reimagined Road Map Viewer by Ana Goetze
  • NEW SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages by Adnette Kamugisha

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP S/HANA Cloud Public Edition in 2508

The SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (3-system landscape) implementation roadmap has been enhanced based on product management input, system functionality changes, and customer feedback. Below are highlights for this release.

  • Introduced a new road map, SAP Activate for Cloud ERP, to guide customers through a cloud ERP implementation. This road map is the continuation of the Provisioning Enablement for SAP Cloud ERP road map and will be expanded to include all the products in the business suite packages.
  • Added road maps, SAP Business Network for Commerce Automation and SAP Ariba, to the combinable road map list in SAP Cloud ALM. This allows for better flexibility when implementing functionality related to the business suite packages.
  • Added a new deliverable, Introduction to SAP Business Suite, and three new tasks to the Discover phase to support learning about the SAP Business Suite along with the GROW with SAP and Rise with SAP journeys.
  • Added references to SAP WalkMe to increase visibility on how SAP WalkMe can help during the implementation.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for Cloud ERP Private Edition

The SAP Activate Methodology content for SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition continues to be enhanced to help guide the customer through the journey of a new implementation, system conversion, and selective data transition following the SAP Clean Core principles. These journeys are accessible by selecting the appropriate journey tag within the single roadmap in road map viewer or individually in SAP Cloud ALM.

Key highlights include:

  • In coordination with the Regional Implementation Group (RIG), several updates have been made in the roadmaps for SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private - New Implementation. 
  • The Discover phase has been updated with a new deliverable Introduction to SAP Business Suite Discover Phase and three new tasks Understand your SAP Cloud Journey, Review the SAP Business Suite Offering and Try SAP. These new tasks aligned with the new Business Suite messaging and content on the sap.com. 
  • All the transition scenarios now include WalkMe Premium guidance and project implementation can leverage the WalkMe as a digitial adoption platform to help enhance user onboarding and enablement throughout their transformation journey. Learn more by reviewing the WalkMe product tag.   
  • During System Conversion customers can leverage the RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench, a tool that offers a single, highly automated, guided system transition processes that integrates all essential technical activities and tools. Learn more by reviewing the SAP Blog - Introducing the RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench.
  • Several updates made to the Data Management workstream, with updated tasks, description, procedure steps and updated accelerators. 
  • In the past few releases, we made updates to the Project Management workstream. The updates include enhanced description of key deliverables, tasks and accelerators and improve workflow efficiency and ensure consistency across project lifecycle. 

 See the release notes for a complete list of all improvements.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP Business Technology Platform

We’re excited to announce the release of new content designed to support customers in the following topics:

  • Implementation of SAP Integration Suite capabilities - It offers a structured approach that leverages best practices, tools, and methodologies to support end-to-end integration project lifecycles — from discovery and planning to implementation and go-live.
  • New content to help assist customers with the migration from SAP Process Orchestration (SAP PO) to the modern, cloud-based SAP Integration Suite and covering the following aspects of the migration project
    • A phased migration approach tailored to your landscape
    • Best practices for analyzing and refactoring integration content
    • Tooling support and checklists for assessment and execution
  • End-to-end implementation guidance for SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) application development capabilities. This content supports teams in identifying business cases, selecting the right cloud development models, and successfully designing, building, and deploying applications using SAP BTP.

 

Updates of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2-system landscape to 3-system landscape 

We are excited to share the latest improvements to the SAP Activate guidance for our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers converting from a 2-system landscape to a 3-system landscape. Since the last major release in January, we have made several updates to the guidance based on our learnings from conversion projects. The key updates are outlined below:

  • Added guidance for the use of the Parallel Line capability after the conversion to the 3-system landscape. This includes the self-enablement tasks in the Prepare and Run phases as well as a new task redirecting to the Parallel Line content in SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-system landscape. (link)
  • Added new task Request Activation of Scope Item 5XU to Use SAP Document and Reporting Compliance into the Prepare phase to trigger the activation checks earlier in the conversion process. (link)
  • Updated task Activate Scope Item 5XU to Use SAP Document and Reporting Compliance in the Realize phase. (link)
  • Added new task, Validate IT contact prior to contract signature, to the Discover phase to ensure the IT contact is available during the conversion weekend. (link)
  • Updated task Create SAP for Me case to allow SAP proactively check your environment to indicate that part of the procedure is only intended for Solution Builder based cases. (link)
  • Added new task, Fix the affected workflows to the Realize phase with instructions on how to fix and re-transport the workflows. Including new accelerator Help - Flexible Workflow - Agent Rules that is added to the task (link)
  • Added a new task, Copy Missing Business Roles from Production System to Test System, to the deliverable Initial System Access After Conversion, to copy business roles from the production tenant to the test tenant when they are missing.

We recommend that you review the detailed release notes in the SAP Activate road map viewer for the latest content updates and view the conversion overview video here. Additionally, bookmark the SAP Community page dedicated to conversion topics here.

 

Updates of SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors

The SAP Activate for SAP SuccessFactors roadmap has been enhanced based on product management input, system functionality changes, and customer feedback. Below are the highlights:

  • Updated phase/workstream graphic to reflect the current deliverable structure in the road map.
  • Expanded the Baseline Activation Service for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP SuccessFactors road map by adding SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central.
  • Updated the several tasks in the Project Management workstream to be consistent and combinable with other road maps.
  • Added references to SAP WalkMe to increase visibility on how SAP WalkMe can help during the implementation.

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool 2508 Release

The 2508 release introduces significant enhancements to the Test Automation Tool (TAT) for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, with a focus on improved usability and intelligent navigation. Key highlights include:

  • Enhanced Post Upgrade Tests Dashboard
    • Advanced Filtering: Easily filter results by Test Plan, Release, Process Type, Status and Application Area
    • Focused Analysis: Reduce information overload and quickly access relevant data
    • Faster Decision-Making: Improved data visualization for faster analysis
  • Joule Navigation Integration
    • Universal Access: Joule navigation is now available across all TAT applications
    • Seamless Movement: Deep links enable effortless movement between test automation modules
    • Prompt-Based Access: Quickly open any TAT app using intuitive prompts

These enhancements greatly boost testing efficiency, minimize manual navigation, and increase user productivity throughout all test automation workflows.

For more details, refer to the blog on the 2508 features in the Test Automation Tool.

 

Run simple – SAP Activate – Accelerate and simplify the adoption of SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

entry.title: IAS (OIDC / OpenID) with ABAP Cloud Developer Trial 2023
entry.content:
This is not an official how-to document but rather sharing experience with the community. This is my first initial setup and will update this as I do more testing with OIDC on ABAP.

At least this is another resource for your journey to setting up OIDC on ABAP. 

My setup at home:

  1. ABAP Cloud Developer Trial 2023 (docker)
  2. BTP Trial Subaccount
  3. Cloud Identity Services Trial

My home setup diagram:

Other requirements:

  • Need to know your home router capabilities.
    • My router (Asus) can handle DDNS
    • It can utilize Let’s encrypt for signing Router certificate.
    • Need to know how to port forward to the ABAP TLS port eg: port 50001
  • You may need Proxy information for your ABAP outbound. Since this is my own home ABAP lab, I don’t use any proxy.
  • Some excellent references and blogs that helped me:
    • ABAP Cloud Developer Trial 2023 Available Now
    • Configuring OIDC between SAP IAS and S/4HANA (ABAP) in a RISE AWS Environment
    • Sign up for a free Trial Account for SAP BTP
    • OpenID Connect for AS ABAP
    • Note 3111813 - OpenID Connect (OIDC): Troubleshooting Note

Lessons learned:

This is not SAML.

IAS need to be able to reach my ABAP system, and since it’s hosted in my Docker Server. Port forwarding is needed to my Docker Server.

Since IAS need to access ABAP, I assumed self-signed SSL Server certificate would not do. It will need ABAP SSL Server to be publicly signed somehow. I found a workaround; my Asus router already have DDNS feature that can also register and utilize a Free Certificate from Let’s Encrypt.

So, after setting up the DDNS, I can use the registered hostname as

https://abapserver.asuscomm.com:50001

The router needs to be configured for port forwarding to ensure that it is reachable from the internet.

Exported the Let's encrypt certificate from ASUS router, then using openssl and sapgenpse , I created a brand new SAPSSLS.PSE with the signed certificate, key and chain certs, and replace it in STRUST.  Here’s the steps.

 

Setting up Cloud Identity Services

1. Create a test user (IAS --> Users & Authorization --> User Management).

This user will need to exist in the ABAP system too. I just created a user jon doe with email jon.doe@xyz.com and make sure it’s verified. This email will need to match the user in ABAP.

 

2. Setup the ABAP as an Application in IAS. IAS --> Application & Resources --> Application and click the Create button.

 

3. Go into the application which is listed on the left side. My example is called ABAP_TRIAL.

4. Go to the OpenID Connection Configuration under Trust.

5. Enter any name, and the part for "Redirect URIs" is important.

The ABAP redirect URI is  /sap/public/bc/sec/oidc/redirect

Some other systems may use /oauth2/callback,  but ABAP does not.

So, for my example it’ll be https://abapserver.asuscomm.com:50001/sap/public/bc/sec/oidc/redirect

Then save it.

6. Select the Single Sign-On --> Subject Name Identifier. I selected Identity Directory with Value Email then save it. I need email as the identifier, this will map nicely with ABAP configuration later.

7. Scroll down to Trust --> Application APIs --> Client Authentication

8. For my initial test, I’m just going to use secrets (password). Scroll down to Secrets and Click the Add button.

9. Enter some description and expiry and select OpenID and save.

10. The next pop up is important. Need to copy and paste it in your notepad for later reference. You can’t retrieve it later.

11. Make sure to save it.

12. Next go to IAS --> Application & Resources tab --> Tenant Settings

13. Select the Single Sign-On --> OpenID Connect Configuration. Cut and paste  this information into your notepad. You will need this later.

14. Next step is to download the public TLS certificate of the IAS tenant. ABAP will need this certificate.

14.1 While at IAS tenant , go to the browser URL and click the front of the URL.  

14.2 Then click certificate is valid

14.3 Select the trial hostname and click the export button and save it to a file. 

15. This file certificate file will be needed to be loaded in ABAP Strust SSL Client Anonymous later.

ABAP OpenID Setup

16. Logon to the ABAP system. Create a test user in ABAP SU01. In my example I copied the existing DEVELOPER user in ABAP and created Jon Doe with email jon.doe@xyz.com .

17. Activate the three required OIDC services. Go to transaction SICF  , enter the Service Name = OIDC and execute

18. Select oidc and right click and activate service

Make sure you select the 2nd Yes to activate all services under oidc

19. Validate all the three services (logout/logoutbc/redirect) under oidc is active.

20. Before you quit SICF, does your ABAP need proxy server? If it does, then go to Menu --> Client --> Proxy Settings

21. In global settings – check the Proxy settings is active and go to HTTPS protocol tab next

22. Enter the proxy server required and save it. 

23. Go to transaction STRUST  and double click the SSL Client SSL Client (Anonymous) and click the change button

24. Click menu Certificate --> Import

 25. Import the previously downloaded certificate from IAS (e.g. _trial-accounts.ondemand.com.cer), then click “add to certificate list”. And save it. You might need to restart your ICM too. 

26. Go to Transaction SOIDC and click the Change button.

 27. Then at Configurations section, there are some additional buttons. Click the new document button and enter the Issuer URL.

URL must not have forward slash / at the end.

Get this info from step 13. Make sure both checkboxes are checked. This allows us to pull in the other URL via discovery.

28. If there are no errors, then it will pull the URL and web key set automatically. Else you need to manually add it.

29. Go back to the Secrets that was copied in step 8. Copy and paste the Client ID into the Client ID field.

30. Leave everything else as default, then scroll down the page and check the Interactive (OIDC Logon) . The authorization and token endpoint should be pre-filled from discovery.  Enter the Redirect URL (the public access ABAP hostname and URI) , eg for my case :

       https://abapserver.asuscomm.com:50001/sap/public/bc/sec/oidc/redirect

31. Next click the Client Secret change button.

32. Go back to the Secrets that was copied in step 8. Copy and paste the Client Secret into the New Client Secret field.

33. Make sure to save the form.

34. Validate the configuration. Select the Issuer and click Validation button and ensure no errors.

35. Since there are no warnings found, the configuration needs to be activated. Select the configuration and click “Set Default Interactive Configuration”. If button is grayed out, make sure to click the save button first and try again.

36. The configuration should have “Default Interactive Configuration” checked. We should be ready for testing.

 

Testing Steps

Just to summarized what was done so far.

  • Network port forwarding
  • Setup Cloud Identity Service
  • Setup ABAP OIDC Connect

37. Start-up Chrome as Incognito and enter ABAP Fiori URL for testing (Fiori already activated in the ABAP cloud trial).

eg:

https://abapserver.asuscomm.com:50001/sap/bc/ui2/flp

38. This should go to ABAP first then it will redirect to IAS and get the IAS logon screen:

If you get error before reaching the logon page, then most likely your redirect URL is incorrect.

Unfortunately for me, this error doesn’t get recorded in IAS.

But check:

  • ABAP redirect SICF services is active
  • ABAP redirect URI is accessible from Internet
  • ABAP redirect URI entered in
    • IAS as in step 5
    • ABAP as in step 31
  • URI does not have trailing slash /

39. Login with the test user id.

40. IAS will do it’s OIDC magic and ideally should log you in directly into Fiori.

entry.title: Using conda-forge in SAP Business Application Studio – my notes
entry.content:
In my previous blog posts, I focused on Using Python in SAP Business Application Studio and Using Jupyter in SAP Business Application Studio with Python's virtual environments. But SAP Business Application Studio (referred to as "BAS" below) also allows you to work with the Conda environments:

Usually, Conda is used when one needs binary package management, and installation with pip fails because of the build requirements that cannot be successfully completed with the tools and authorizations a developer has in their BAS dev space.

👉 At the time of writing this post, using Conda might require additional commercial licenses from Anaconda, Inc. if downloading their tools and/or packages from their `default` channel. This might be a valid case for you, but this blog post covers only the use of the community-driven `conda-forge` channel and the minimum tools required to use it. To the best of my knowledge, I discuss only the technical setup here, but you might need to check any license implications for the dependencies of a project you are working on.

Install miniforge

Miniforge is a minimal installer for Conda and Mamba with the conda-forge channel set as the default (and only) channel.

Follow the installation steps, for example from https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge?tab=readme-ov-file#unix-like-platforms-macos-linux--wsl

Download and run the installation script.

curl --location --remote-name --output-dir ~/tmp "https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Miniforge3-$(uname)-$(uname -m).sh"

bash ~/tmp/Miniforge3-$(uname)-$(uname -m).sh -b

 Configure conda

Activate conda and its base environment.

eval "$(/home/user/miniforge3/bin/conda shell.$(basename "${SHELL}") hook)"

 Initialize conda (it will add the shell's integration).

conda init

To prevent the conda's base environment from being activated on startup (because it will be taken care of by the Python extension), run the following command:

conda config --set auto_activate_base false

For changes to take effect, close and re-open your current shell.

Update conda's base environment to the latest packages from the community-maintained conda-forge channel.

conda update -n base --all --yes

You can also use the faster mamba command instead of conda. Both are parts of the Miniforge installation.

Point Python extension to your Conda executable

In Terminal, check the location of the conda command, which should be something like /home/user/miniforge3/condabin/conda:

which conda

 In Settings, open python.condaPath and switch to the Remote tab. Input the value.

Create a .conda environment in your project

Open your project folder in BAS.

From the command palette, start the command Python: Create Environment..., then Conda environment type...

...and select the required Python version from the list:

You should see the message that the environment is created and set as the active one for the project.

Open a new Terminal session, and you should see the .conda environment set.

You can check the list of environments with the command:

conda env list

Install IPyKernel in your .conda environment

Unlike in a "venv" virtual environment, the Python extension might not automatically install IPyKernel in a conda environment. You need to install it manually.

In Terminal, with the .conda environment set in the command line, run the command:

conda install ipykernel --yes

Check with the command

conda list ipykernel

Select the .conda env in your notebook

Now, you can open your project's Jupyter notebook, select the .conda environment, and execute the code 🤓

You should be ready to work with conda-forge in SAP Business Application Studio now! 

Please share your tips in the comments!

In my other blog posts, I focused on:
🐍Using Python in SAP Business Application Studio, and
🪐 Using Jupyter in SAP Business Application Studio.

------

-Vitaliy, aka @Sygyzmundovych

entry.title: Hands-on Tutorial: SAP Databricks
entry.content:
With SAP Databricks we now have a dedicated environment for Data Scientists within the SAP Business Data Cloud. This blog gives a practical introduction to this bespoke Databricks edition by implementing a bare bones demand forecast. SAP Databricks includes important functionality beyond what is explained in this entry-level tutorial., for example data sharing, experiment tracking or AutoML.

The integration of SAP Databricks is adding a new option to the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), giving customers more choice when creating custom extensions or applications. Existing components on the BTP, which you might already be familiar with, remain very relevant and strategic, such as:

  • SAP AI Core, which provides for example access to a long list of Large Language Models through its Generative AI Hub. Some of the models are even hosted on SAP's own physical infrastructure, giving increased security (currently Mistral and Aleph Alpha).
  • SAP Document AI, which extracts information from documents such as PDFs, Excel, images, ...
  • SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Datasphere, with their built-in multi-model capabilities, ie Machine Learning, embeddings generation for Text, Vector engine, Graph engine, Geospatial 
  • SAP Build, Joule Studio for adding new skills to our digital assistant Joule, and the ability to create new AI agents on the roadmap. This blog (series) on SAP's AI Agent Architecture by our CTO and Chief AI Officer Philipp Herzig gives an excellent overview of the wider picture.

And remember to check on the AI/ML functionality that has already been built into SAP standard applications, or what is in the pipeline to be released. Both released and planned functionality is shown in the Roadmap Explorer.

Note: All data, code and images that are used in this blog can be downloaded from this repository: Hands-on Tutorial SAP Databricks. In that repository you find the individual files but also the whole project exported as Databricks Archive.

Before we get going, big thanks to Stojan Maleschlijski for all the great collaboration, including exploring the SAP Databricks capabilities together! @stojanm 

 

Table of contents

  • Use Case 
  • Architecture
  • Prerequisites
  • Upload data
  • Explore the data
  • Create a forecast with SAP Databricks
  • Schedule a forecast with SAP Databricks
  • Good to know
    • Base file
    • Lineage & Table usage insights
    • Visuals
  • Summary

 

Use Case

This blog aims to give a first introduction for carrying out a Machine Learning project on SAP Databricks. Trying to simulate a demand forecast, we will predict how many nights people spend in a hotel in Switzerland. We use some granular data that is kindly shared by the Swiss Statistics department.

A Data Scientist (you) creates a monthly forecast and sets up a schedule for the forecast to be updated every month.  This data would then become part of a business process, maybe you want to provide the data to business users in a dashboard. This tutorial however focusses solely on creating and scheduling the forecast in SAP Databricks.

It's a simple time-series forecasting example, but the concept is still extremely relevant for so many different business requirements. Instead of forecasting how many visitors are staying overnight, you might need to forecast your sales quantities, your cash flow or even for topics that don't come immediately to mind. One customer for instance is using time-series forecasting to improve the data quality of external data that is loaded into the system. If a new value is outside the predicted range, there might be a data quality issue and IT can follow up, whether the data is correct or whether indeed a data quality issue cropped up.

 

Architecture

In a productive system a typical architecture and data flow would look like this.

  1. A Data Product is pushed into the Business Data Cloud Object Store
  2. This Data Product is shared with SAP Databricks
  3. SAP Databricks creates and saves a forecast as DeltaTable into the Object Store
  4. This table is registered as Custom Data Product in the Business Data Cloud
  5. SAP Datasphere installs the Custom Data Product, making it accessible for further data modelling and visualisation in SAP Analytics Cloud

 

The architecture of this hands-on exercise is focused purely on getting some familiarity with SAP Databricks. The only interface we will be using is SAP Databricks. We use it to upload the data and to go through the steps of a Machine Learning project.

 

Prerequisites

Getting started is pretty easy.

  • You will just need to have access to an instance of SAP Databricks. This could be the SAP Business Data Cloud trial.
  • Some familiarity with SQL and especially Python would be very useful. 
  • And maybe just some curiosity to try something new.

 

Upload data

Start by bringing the historic data, on which we want to train a model, into the system. Upload the dataset OVERNIGHTSTAYS.csv with the Graphical User Interface of SAP Databricks. Follow the steps shown in this screencam. In case that you are working with the trial, then you need to change the Catalog drop-down as shown to "workspace".

The data is uploaded. it is showing in the Catalog as (Delta)Table. Physically it is stored in the Object Store. The table's Overview tab lists the column names and their data types:

 

Move to the table's "Sample Data" tab to see some of the uploaded rows.

The first lines shows that in January 2022 there were 392.805 nights spent by Swiss residents in the area of Graubünden. In case you are not that familiar with Swiss geography, Graubünden is the largest Canton in Switzerland, it's in the Alps and includes beautiful places like St. Moritz and Davos. 

 

Explore the data 

You have two options to explore the data in SAP Databricks.

  • Either query the DeltaTable directly with SQL
  • Or use a Notebook, in which you can use both SQL or Python

Data exploration with the SQL Editor

Let's look closer into the data. You can start with some SQL statements. You can go into the SQL Editor and type in your own syntax. The screencam shows two simple examples. We learn for instance that we have data from January 2022 to May 2025 to work with.

  • SELECT * from overnightstays
  • SELECT min(MONTH), max(month) from overnightstays

 

Or describe what you are looking for and have SAP Databrick's write the SQL for you! Click that small red-ish star icon to toggle on the Databricks Assistant.

 

Just try out what you are interested in. I was wondering for example:

  • which regions are in overnightstays?
  • use table overnightstays to determine how many overnight stays were they by region, sort the results
  • use table overnightstays to summarise overnightstays by countryofresidence

 

It turns out that most overnight stays in Switzerland are by Swiss residents, followed by German residents. Maybe surprisingly residents from the United States are a close third.

 

Data exploration with a Notebook

Now continue the data exploration in a Notebook. Databricks Notebooks are quite special in that they can contain more than one scripting language. SAP Databricks supports both SQL as well as Python. The Notebook created in this section can also be downloaded from the repository.

Begin by creating a folder in which we will save our Notebooks. Go into the "Workspace" section, which is where such files are kept together. Within your user's workspace create a folder called "Demand forecast".

 

In that new folder create a first Notebook as shown in the next screencam. Rename it to "Demand forecast". And add a short header in Markdown at the top. Markdown is a common way to add comments and context to the code in a Notebook. Adding "#" character at the beginning of a line formats the text as top-level heading. Two "#" characters make it a second-level heading, and so on. Without any "#" character the following text is formatted just normally as plain text. 

To add the Markdown, you need to change the cell's language selector to "Markdown" as shown in the screencam. Enter your text. When done, click outside the cell and the formatting kicks in.

 

Since the cells can also execute SQL code, add the most recent SQL statement from the SQL Editor.

SELECT
  COUNTRYOFRESIDENCE,
  SUM(OVERNIGHTSTAYS) AS total_overnightstays
FROM
  workspace.default.overnightstays
GROUP BY
  COUNTRYOFRESIDENCE
ORDER BY
  total_overnightstays DESC

 

The screencam shows how a new cell can be added to the Notebook, by hovering with the mouse at the bottom of the cell above. Select "Code" as cell type. Change the cell's language selector to "SQL", paste the code and run it with the blue play button. You will see the same result as before in the "SQL Editor".

 

Let's switch to Python for the data exploration so that you have tried all the options. Create a new Code cell, its language selector might already be on "Python" by default. Begin by loading the data into a PySpark DataFrame using the table's fully qualified path.

overnightstays_sdf = spark.read.table("workspace.default.overnightstays")

 

Aggregate the data by month and look at the results. The display command initially shows the data as table, but it also comes with a Graphical User interface to quickly create a plot. Follow the steps in the screencam to create a line chart, to see how the numbers have evolved over time. There is a clear pattern, that especially in July and August the numbers are at their highest.

import pyspark.sql.functions as F
display(overnightstays_sdf.groupBy("month").agg(F.sum("overnightstays").alias("overnightstays")))

 

Now explore, whether we can visually get a feel for an overall trend in the data, whether the numbers tend to go up or down over time. Have the Assistant do the work of writing the code with this request:

Create a new DataFrame that has the year in a new column. aggregate by year and show the result in a plotly chart

Plotly is a very common Python charting library. And indeed, when looking at the yearly totals, the numbers are increasing for the years.  The year 2025 is not meaningful yet in this chart as the dataset only contains January to May for that year.

 

Create a forecast with SAP Databricks

During the above data exploration we saw that the data has a trend (numbers are increasing over time) and some seasonality (ie numbers are largest in the summer). Let's train a Machine Learning that picks up on such patterns and can estimate future values. The Notebook created in this section can also be downloaded from the repository.

In case you are unsure about how to implement the following 4 code blocks, then this screencam will guide you along. It shows in a quick scroll through what the output should look like.

 

Read the historic data again into a PySpark DataFrame.

overnightstays_sdf = spark.read.table("workspace.default.overnightstays")

 

Since we want to create a monthly forecast on the total values, aggregate the history by month. Since we are working with the PySpark DataFrame, the built-in Spark engine is doing the work.

import pyspark.sql.functions as F
overnightstaysmonthly_sdf = overnightstays_sdf.groupBy("month").agg(F.sum("overnightstays").alias("overnightstays"))
display(overnightstaysmonthly_sdf)

 

The data needs to be prepared further, so that the Python package called Prophet can train a time-series model on it.

# Convert Spark DataFrame to Pandas DataFrame (the time series algorithm requires a Pandas DataFrame)
overnightstaysmonthly_df = overnightstaysmonthly_sdf.toPandas()

# Sort the DataFrame by date
overnightstaysmonthly_df = overnightstaysmonthly_df.sort_values('month')

# Rename the columns, as required by the time-series algoritm Prophet
overnightstaysmonthly_df = overnightstaysmonthly_df.rename(columns={'month': 'ds', 'overnightstays': 'y'})

 

We want to use the Prophet package for the forecast, which still needs to be installed. Here we install it directly from the Notebook. However, in the "Good to know" section below you see a more elegant way of using additional Python package, by creating your own customised Base environment.

pip install prophet==1.1.7

 

Everything is now in place to finally train the time-series model. The following block of code contains multiple steps. It is useful to run these steps together under the "with mlflow.start_run() section as this allows to log information about the training run in SAP Databricks.  The following code:

  • Trains the time series model
  • Creates a DataFrame with the future 12 months that are to be forecasted
  • Creates a forecast for the known past and the future 12 months
  • Calculates  and logs the model's accuracy on the known history
  • Plots and logs the known history against the predicted values
  • Logs the number of records that were used during training

Yes, in a real project this code would be even more elaborate. For example you may want to try different model configurations to get even better forecast accuracy. And the accuracy should ideally be calculated on a hold-out sample. Currently the code uses the same data for training as well as for checking the model's accuracy. The accuracy should really be calculated on data the model has never seen before. 

import pandas as pd
from prophet import Prophet
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_percentage_error
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import mlflow, mlflow.tracking._model_registry.utils

mlflow.tracking._model_registry.utils._get_registry_uri_from_spark_session = lambda: "databricks-uc"

with mlflow.start_run():

    # Initialize the Prophet model
    model = Prophet()

    # Fit the model
    model.fit(overnightstaysmonthly_df)

    # Create a DataFrame that contains all dates for which a prediction is required, the future 12 months but also the known past for comparison
    datestopredict_df = model.make_future_dataframe(periods=12, freq='MS')

    # Forecast the future and known past
    forecast_df = model.predict(datestopredict_df)

    # Plot the predictions together with known past
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
    ax.plot(forecast_df['ds'], forecast_df['yhat'], label='Forecast', color='red')
    ax.plot(overnightstaysmonthly_df['ds'], overnightstaysmonthly_df['y'], label='Historical Data')
    ax.fill_between(forecast_df['ds'], forecast_df['yhat_lower'], forecast_df['yhat_upper'], color='red', alpha=0.3)
    ax.set_title('Demand forecast')
    ax.set_xlabel('Month')
    ax.set_ylabel('Total Overnightstays')
    ax.legend()
    ax.grid(True)
    plt.show()

    # Calculate and log model accuracy, here MAPE on training data
    overnightstaysmonthly_df[["ds"]] = overnightstaysmonthly_df[["ds"]].apply(pd.to_datetime)
    anctualsandpredicted_df = overnightstaysmonthly_df[['ds', 'y']].merge(forecast_df[['ds', 'yhat']], on='ds', how='inner', suffixes=('_left', '_right'))
    prophet_mape = mean_absolute_percentage_error(anctualsandpredicted_df['y'], anctualsandpredicted_df['yhat'])
    mlflow.log_metric("mape", prophet_mape)

    # Log the chart in the Unity Catalog / Experiment
    mlflow.log_figure(fig, "Forecast.png") 

    # Log the size of the training dataset
    mlflow.log_metric("rowcount_training", overnightstaysmonthly_df.shape[0])

 

Run the above code and we see our prediction!

 

To persist the forecast, save it as DeltaTable. From here the data can be made available to SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud. That part is outside the scope of this tutorial, please check the documentation.

forecast_sdf = spark.createDataFrame(forecast_df)
forecast_sdf.write.mode("overwrite").saveAsTable("workspace.default.overnightstays_forecast")

 

The forecast is saved as DeltaTable, that means you can see it in the Catalog!

 

The information that was logged during the training is now available in the Experiments section. The model's MAPE (Median Absolute Percentage Error) is at 1.4%, 41 records were used during training and we can see the chart that compares actuals to predictions. Especially when trying out different settings for the Machine Learning algorithm, this tracking becomes very useful, for instance to select which configuration to use for the prediction.

 

Schedule

Everything we need for our demand forecast is implemented and we can run it manually. That means we are also good to have it automated with a schedule. Straight from the notebook you can define the scheduling logic, ie the recurring interval and whether you want any notifications. The notebooks can also be triggered through APIs if you prefer.

 

Good to know

A few things that might be good to know.

 

Base file

In the above code the Python package Prophet is installed directly from within a Notebook. That's ok, but not ideal for ongoing use. If you were repeatedly re-running all cells from the Notebook, then Python will try to re-install the package every time. It's generally better to centrally specify the packages you know you will be using long term. This also ensures consistency across projects and developers. In SAP Databricks you can specify reusable / shareable lists of Python packages that are to be installed through Base environments.

Create a Base environment by creating a file called base_env_prophet.yaml with this content:

dependencies:
  - prophet==1.1.7

 

With this base file in place, you can

  • Step 1: Remove the pip install command from the "020 Demand forecast" Notebook

 

  • Step 2: Specify that the Notebook will use the base file instead, to determine which packages to install. Here you can also select the Environment version. These are documented here.

 

To test out that the Package is correctly installed through the base file, clear the environment as shown in the screencam and run the Python code in the cells.

 

Lineage & Table usage insights

Now that the table "overnightstays" has been used a few times, check out the lineage, which shows where the table is used and the statistics on how heavily that table is used. 

 

Visuals

From the distance most Notebooks look very much alike at first glance. I heard some great feedback that some visual / image on top of the notebook would help to differentiate. In the repository you find a few examples, in case you would like to use those to distinguish between Data Exploration, AI/ML Sandboxing and AI/ML Deployment.

Upload any images that you want to use into the Workspace. To keep things tidy I am creating a separate folder for them.

 

These images can then be shown in a Markup cell.

 

Summary

SAP Databricks is adding a dedicated Data Science environment to the SAP landscape. After this hands-on experience you hopefully have a first feel for how a Data Scientist can enrich the data in SAP Business Data Cloud with Machine Learning.

For your own projects, you will want to check out the documentation:

  • SAP Databricks documentation by SAP
  • SAP Databricks documentation by Databricks

 

I hope you enjoyed getting hands-on with SAP Databricks!

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in July
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in July

Another month with two great new release deliveries ✨
Learn more in my short top features video in July 2025 on YouTube 📺
In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs.

 

 

My top features in July

 

Data Integration & Connectivity

Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) as Source for Your Replication Flow

After delivering SFTP as a target already in May this year, you can now also use SFTP connections as sources in replication flows to any supported target.

➡️   More information:

  • Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) as Source for Your Replication Flow
  • Generic SFTP Connections

 

Transport Objects Between File Spaces

You can now export objects from and import objects to file spaces, meaning a space based on the embedded object store with file-based artifacts.

➡️   More information

 

Task Chains

New Layout Option in Task Chain Toolbar

The options in the task chain editor toolbar have been re-arranged and a new layout option was added. The new layout option allows you to rearrange the visual display of a task chain on the canvas, from top-to-bottom (the default), or left-to-right.

➡️   More information

 

Connection Type Generic HTTP

With the new connection type, you can connect to external systems and add tasks that are exposed by REST-based APIs to task chains. For this purpose, we have introduced the new API Tasks connection feature, which is supported only for Generic HTTP connections.

➡️   More information

 

Running API Tasks in a Task Chain

The generic HTTP connection is the prerequisite to provide the ability of running tasks in a task chain that use a REST-based API to access external systems.

➡️   More information

 

New Notification Task Object in Task Chains

SAP Datasphere now allows users to set up additional email notification within a task chain, in addition to the notification specified for completion of the entire task chain. Users drag the new Notification Task object to any point in the sequence of tasks run in a task chain and then specify the subject and message for this new email notification. These new notifications use the same recipient list as the email notification maintained at the task chain level.

➡️   More information

 

Self-Service Enhancements

Enable Multi-Availability Zones for SAP HANA Cloud

Use the Enable SAP HANA Multi-Availability Zones option on the Tenant Configuration page to create a synchronous replica of the main system on a system in a different region. The synchronous replica system has a high-availability setup that can take over processing when necessary.

➡️   More information:

  • Configure the Size of Your SAP Datasphere Tenant
  • Creating and Configuring Your SAP Datasphere Tenant

 

Enabling of SAP HANA for SQL data warehousing on Your SAP Datasphere Tenant

Administrators can now create the mapping between their SAP Datasphere tenant and their SAP Business Technology Platform account to enable SAP HANA for SQL data warehousing themselves, rather than needing to raise a ticket. Both environments for Kyma and Cloud Foundry are supported and the same information as previously required for the ticket with Organization ID and Space ID is required to be able to do the instance mapping.

➡️   More information

 

 

 

Webinar Series: Architecting Your SAP BDC Journey – From Data to Intelligence 

There was a great architecture webinar series about SAP Business Data Cloud and various architecture deep dive topics. Thanks to @Gaurish-Dessai, @PaulKurchina, @helmut_grimm and team.

 

Sessions

Speakers

Data Inspired – Successful concepts for data-driven organizations

Paul Kurchina, Dr. Sebastian Wernicke, Helmut Grimm, Gaurish Dessai

Unleash your Data and AI with Irfan Khan and Timo Elliott

Paul Kurchina, Irfan Khan & Timo Elliott

Unpacking SAP Business Data Cloud for Enterprise Architects

Ralph Richter, Gaurish Dessai, Axel Meier, Amogh Umbarkar

Enterprise Architects guide on SAP BW Modernization

Jason Luo & Gaurish Dessai

Planning your Transition Paths to SAP Business Data Cloud

Naveen Dumpa & Jason Luo

SAP Business Data Cloud and Databricks – Stronger Together

Michelle Wiktorsson, Qi Su & Habeebuddin Mohammad

SAP Business Data Cloud & Databricks in Action with Demos

Michelle Wiktorsson, Gaurish Dessai, Rithivika Acharya & Peter Schmidt

SAP BDC Series Wrap up – Insights, Learnings, and the Road Ahead

Paul Kurchina, Ralph Richter, Gaurish Desai, Prakash Nanduri & Timo Elliott

Find the session details, slides and recordings here
➡️   Recordings and Slides from webinar series 'Architecting Your SAP Business Data Cloud Journey'

 

Learning Update

The number of learning opportunities are constantly growing and our colleagues in the learning department have delivered the next milestone with a new instructor-led class about SAP Business Data Cloud. Learn more in the blog from @MarkGreen 
➡️   Learn SAP Business Data Cloud with our new instructor-led class

 

Blog series for our Japanese Community

  • SAP Business Data Cloud : SAP Analytics Cloud のプロビジョニング
  • SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) のプロビジョニングガイド
  • SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) 関連情報 まとめブログ
  • SAP Business Data Cloud: オブジェクトストア 入門編
  • SAP Business Data Cloud の概要

 

My favorite blogs in July

This blog describes the next major enhancement of the SAP Datasphere catalog, which is now also enabled to harvest metadata from SAP BW/4HANA. Get all the details in @GaetanSaulnier blog
➡️   SAP Datasphere catalog - Harvesting from SAP BW/4HANA

If you are interested on SAP AI Foundation, SAP BDC and SAP Databricks then check the two blogs from @san_tran below 👇
➡️   Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive (1/2)
➡️   Unlocking SAP AI Foundation capabilities in SAP Databricks: A technical deep dive (2/2)

 

More blogs to check out 👇

  • The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The Context of Business Steering
  • SAP Databricks: Building an Intelligent Enterprise with AI Unleashed – Part 2
  • SAP Business Data Cloud - Performance Recommendations for Story Designers
  • SAP Databricks: Building an Intelligent Enterprise with AI Unleashed – Part 1
  • SAP Datasphere Replication Flow Logs: Monitoring & Insights
  • Inside SAP Series Mid-Year Wrap-Up: Powered by Practice, Driven by Data
  • Session 1 Recap – Concepts for Building a Data-Driven Organization
  • Recordings and Slides from webinar series 'Architecting Your SAP Business Data Cloud Journey'
  • Announcing SAP Business Data Cloud Data Architecture Miniseries for SAP Partners!
  • New: Value Analytics for SAP Fieldglass
  • Elevating HR’s role in the C-suite
  • Session 6 Recap: SAP Business Data Cloud + Databricks – Why They’re Stronger Together
  • [Register Now] Introducing People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud Webinar (August 7)
  • Learn SAP Business Data Cloud with our new instructor-led class
  • Embark on your Learning Journey with 'Exploring SAP Business Data Cloud' and get certified
  • Session 5 Recap & Highlights - Planning Your Transition Paths to SAP Business Data Cloud
  • BW-Like Authorizations in Datasphere (DSP)
  • What's New in SAP Analytics Cloud Modeling Extensions & Integration QRC3 2025 Release
  • SAP BDC Ecosystem
  • Unlocking the Power of SAP BW/4HANA Metadata in the SAP Datasphere catalog in BDC
  • SAP Datasphere catalog - Harvesting from SAP BW/4HANA
  • The Future of Planning in Excel: The SAP Analytics Cloud Add-in as a Strategic Frontend – Part 1/3
  • SAP Business Data Cloud: Secure by Design and Intelligent by Default
  • Automating Flat File Loads in SAP Datasphere Using Generic SFTP Connections
  • Shaping the Future of SAP data and analytics solutions
  • A Beginners guide to SAP BDC
  • SAP Analytics Business Intelligence Statement of Direction – July 2025 update
  • Announcement: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Rethinking People Analytics for AI: Introducing People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud

 

Find more information and related blog posts on the topic page for SAP Datasphere. You will find further product information on our Community with various subpages about Business Content, the SAP BW Bridge as well as content for Best Practices & Troubleshooting. Also check out the new support content for SAP Datasphere on SAP Help for troubleshooting and analysis guides, how-to guides, technical details, and more.

Find out how to unleash the power of your business data with SAP’s free learning content on SAP Datasphere. It’s designed to help you enrich your data projects, simplify the data landscape, and make the most out of your investment. Check out even more role-based learning resources and opportunities to get certified in one place on  SAP Learning site.

entry.title: SAP Discovery Center Expands and Welcomes the SAP BTP Guidance Framework
entry.content:
We are excited to announce that SAP Discovery Center has expanded to include even more SAP Business Technology Platform expert insights and strategic guidance. The SAP BTP Guidance Framework has now found a new home in SAP Discovery Center.  
 
You have consistently praised SAP Discovery Center for being an excellent resource for all things SAP BTP. Including, BTP Service and AI Feature catalog info, cost estimations, and implementation guidance. Your feedback always remains the same – “It’s so nice to find all the info in one place.”. With your feedback in mind, we are excited to bring these two key resources closer together in one location.  
 
What does this mean for you? 
You might remember the previous SAP Discovery Center homepage, which welcomed you with four main tiles – Missions, Reference Architectures, SAP BTP Services, and SAP Business AI. What you will notice now is that the Reference Architectures tile has been replaced by a brand-new tile – SAP BTP Guidance Framework.  
 

 

Don’t worry, you can still easily find all reference architectures on the new SAP BTP Guidance Framework landing page. 
 
 
 
If you are new to the SAP BTP Guidance Framework, it provides clear direction and a structured approach to adopting SAP technologies. It houses expert-curated resources to help you make smart decisions and is tailored for architects, developers, and administrators.  
Some of the key resources you will find are: 
  • Methodologies 
  • Reference Architectures 
  • Guides 
If you want to learn more about the SAP BTP Guidance Framework and its offerings, please check out my other blog post – SAP BTP Guidance Framework: A Compass for Architects, Developers, and Administrators where I explore the topic in much more detail. 
 
You Might Also be Interested In 
The Guidance Framework has also been presented as a live YouTube series with role-based episodes. Watch the recordings available on YouTube: 
  1. SAP BTP Guidance Framework Series: How-to Empower Architects, Developers, and Administrators 
  2. SAP BTP Guidance Framework: How-to Empower Developers 
  3. SAP BTP Guidance Framework: How-to Empower Administrators 
 
Stay Tuned 
We are currently driving a blog post series diving deeper into the SAP BTP Guidance Framework. Stay tuned for the next blog post covering the newest addition to the framework – SAP BTP AI Best Practices.
